Mr Speaker, I have had no specific conversation exactly on that point was that belt she will recognise when she has a chance to look on it is that cat fishing is referred to in the course of the white paper and if these offences are fried representation, they may be on the statute book. It might be good to look at what it might be, and make sure that we discussed it with our colleagues in the Home Office. Mr Speaker, can I think the secretary of state but this report. It is in line with the select committee. I am from neighbouring last November when 100 women MPs from 100 different countries met in this chamber in time and time again we were hearing how the abuse that women politicians get as temporary them from doing their jobs, and a direct attack against democracy, and they were looking to the UK to take global leadership. Thank you Secretary of State for taking that leadership and can you confirm that duty of care is not censorship, it is not curtailing freedom of the price, but it is going to help protect democracy as well as individuals? I can't confirm that. It is important to repeat that this is a process that we believe is necessary to level the playing field. These are abuses that if they were happening in any other environment could be -- would be controlled. The point that she makes about the abuse that female politicians has to endure, very much echoes the honourable lady who speaks by the Scottish Nationalist party, and she is right. It is not just politicians. Female journalists and others in public life have to endure the same. It is unacceptable and must stop. I am pleased to see that the Home Secretary have the concerns of our committees about extremist terrorist companies and I look forward to the action on this. Can I press further on the issue of the integrity of our elections, referendums, and our democracy on a day-to-day basis? About the millions being spent on advertising, dark money, going on at this moment, does he not agree that we need action today, not waiting months for that to come? across England and Wales. Many packaged bank accounts now, the travel insurance but many people only discover what the are not covered for when they need to claim. This causes huge distress and expense for a family from my constituency this summer so can we have a debate on what more banks should do to be upfront with people at Clifton the outset that what they are covered for? That is a good point, we all have experiences are being sold extras that then somehow don't happen when you try and claim on them so I think the honourable lady with a good point and again I would encourage her to raise that with Treasury ministers next week.

Thank you Mr Speaker, my constituent's mother Nadia is Ukrainian and on her last visit from the UK it coincided with the Russian annexation of Ukraine. Sorry, the the Russian invasion and disruption of Ukraine. The Home Office advice was not the travel at that time and that the actually stayed longer than her visa and applied for leave to remain, which is at hand home as soon as she possibly could. She has now applied for a family visa to visit her family but it has been turned down because she did not properly highlight the withdrawn application. I have asked for a review of this and immigration officials are sticking to their guns is up and later make a statement outlining what our options are for me as a parliamentarian to help Nadia get a Visa to visit her young grandchildren watermark I congratulate the honourable gentleman for raising this particular constituency case. As he often does in this place. And if you'd like me to take it up with ministers on his behalf perhaps he would write to me the details? Thank you Mr Speaker. I note how many members across the house are currently face down on a smartphone and tablet and I realise they are multitasking but there is now growing evidence about the link between the use of technology such as what funds and promotional health particularly among young people. Can we have a debate on government time about what more can be done to get the big tech companies to take this issue seriously? I agree with the honourable gentleman that we spent far too much time on technology and particularly for young people are thinking about skills are saying to the students that they can't have their devices during the course of the day, it is a contentious subject but I certainly support it personally. The honourable death is right, it is a key issue the sense we are undertaking a massive experiment because there is no regulation around us. In her attempt to seek a backbench debates that all honourable members can share views and we can debate that with ministers. The resolution foundation report calling for Universal Credit roll out to be stopped is the seventh in the last six months. I have had constituents who have had applications that have been never received, documents that have been lost, delaying several weeks on top of the five weeks design that the had to wait before they received their first payment. It is clearly not fit for purpose or can we have a debate on government time on new Social Security policy and the need British people? I have to say, for a new social contract with the Universal Credit is designed to help, it is a better, simpler and more flexible system that helps more people into work. She may not like it, but that is the truth of it. Under the old system if you worked one-minute over 16 hours they knew what you're all job-seekers allowance. Universal Credit or requires you to make one application and it makes sure that work always pays. Research published this month shows that Universal Credit means 8 million EU extra for the economy, an extra 200,000 people in work. And an extra 130 million more working hours every year for those already in a job. Now she raises an important point which is about the wallet of Universal Credit, and she will be aware that the government is listening very carefully to the evidence in this place and from users. We have raised advances to 100% of the first month's payment so she is not right to say that people are having to wait five weeks, that is something not the case. We have made it quicker and easier for people to get their -- get their first payments so everyone can get their money on the very same day. We have introduced an overlap for those already receiving housing benefit to make sure they have a new transition, a smooth transition onto the new system. We continue to look very carefully at the roll-out to improve it but said they say we should halt it is to deny the many people the opportunity and Mr Speaker, you would not limited time but I could give her countless examples of people who have really benefited Universal Credit, getting into work for the first time. My

urn:contentItem:5VYJ-C6K1-DY08-308V-00000-00Live House of Commons - 11:10 AM GMT2019-04-24T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:07:53ZLexisNexisU.K. NATIONALLive House of Commons - 11:10 AM GMT

Live coverage of the day's proceedings in the House of Commons including (estimated timings) 1230 Urgent Question: Parliamentary Standards - 1310 Finance (No.2) Bill: Committee Stage.

Speech to text transcript:

This copy is computer generated. Text will vary in accuracy due to speaker dialect and audio quality issues.

in Northern Ireland and we should all of us in this house continue to send every officer our full support. I angry -- I agree entirely with the sentiments expressed, but can I bring him back to the issue of the border. I agree with him about the ends he tries to achieve but the fundamental problem is the means. We know his own party and the DUP will not accept the current backstop and the only way the government plans to avoid the backstop is to deliver a so called invisible border, but last week we saw a leaked Home Office presentation stating that, and I quote, no government worldwide currently has a system in place and 2030 is the time for the UK and there is currently no budget for either a pilot or for the programme itself.

So can the Minister tell us are the Home Office wrong? Well, I'm not going to comment on alleged leaks from government departments, but what I can say to the house is that the government has allocated #20 million to invest in work on alternative measures that would bring benefits in terms of seamless trade, both to the border between Northern Ireland and Ireland, but which, if successful, more generally, could be applied to give us smart borders on all of the UK's external borders and perhaps offer us export opportunities for that technology as well. It's interesting what the minister says, but the Home Office also says that there are six problems with deploying the technological solutions. It is expensive, there is no budget. It has to operate with 28 different government agencies. It has to operate on both sides of the border. It won't be deliverable until 2030. With covenant has a poor track record on big tech projects. And nobody in the world has done anything similar. So that, Mr Speaker, is hardly a recipe for success. The real answer to the Northern Ireland border question is staring the government in the face. 28 months ago and two Brexit secretaries ago I told the minister from this dispatch box that the only way to avoid a hard border was staying in a customs union and, of course, the alignment of all rules and regulations and he himself said three years ago that for anybody to pretend otherwise he said flies in the face of reality. That was the truth then and it remains the truth today, so why will the government just not wake up to it? I did say to the Right Honourable lady in our previous exchange that there is a #20 million budget that has already been earmarked for this work. It is also the case, whatever the Right Honourable lady might be reading in the newspapers about timetables, that not just the UK but the European Union has committed itself to try to get these alternative measures agreed by 2020. That is not an undertaking or commitment that the European Commission has entered into lightly and without some thought and analysis about the chances of achieving that. But could I say to the Right Honourable lady, the solution she identifies of needing to have a frictionless border on the island of Ireland is what is delivered by the government's withdrawal agreement. Therefore, what she should be doing is urging her Right Honourable and honourable friends to vote for what the government is proposing instead of rejecting it and therefore blocking the Brexit which her party's manifesto commits her to. Mr Speaker, we've heard it all before, let's face it. The only point the Minister didn't make this time was that Britain must be able to establish her own international trade agreements. Perhaps he has been listening to Nancy Pelosi who made it clear that if the UK Government disrupted the open border in Northern Ireland, we could forget about a free trade deal with the US. So the government will spend millions giving Donald Trump the red carpet and golden carriage treatment in June and maybe the state banquet might be worth it so long as he is forced to sit next to Greta Thunberg. He could have greater on one side and David Attenborough on the other and that would be three hours well spent. But the truth is that it will all be a giant waste of taxpayer money because the US Congress will never agree to a trade deal unless we have a solution for the Irish border that will actually work. And this government simply doesn't have one.

urn:contentItem:5XBD-VRJ1-F03R-N2D6-00000-00LIVE: Lawmakers grill Mark Zuckerberg about the big plan Facebook created to upend the way we send money around the globe (FB)2019-10-23T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:07:53ZLexisNexisLIVE: Lawmakers grill Mark Zuckerberg about the big plan Facebook created to upend the way we send money around the globe (FB)Lisa Eadicicco

Oct 23, 2019( The Business Insider: http://www.businessinsider.com/ Delivered by Newstex) Getty Facebook[1] CEO Mark Zuckerberg is testifying before the House Financial Services Committee on Wednesday to answer questions from lawmakers about its ambitions in the finance sector through the Libra currency it announced earlier this year. The hearing comes after key partners like Paypal, Visa, and Mastercard backed out of the project earlier this month following heavy scrutiny of the project from lawmakers. In his opening testimony, Zuckerberg reiterated that the company will not support launching the Libra system at all until all regulatory concerns have been met. He also said that he believes pressing forward with Libra is important for the United States to keep up with China, which he said is moving forward with similar ideas.

Visit Business Insider's homepage for more stories.[2] Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg is testifying[3] before the House Financial Services Committee on Wednesday, where lawmakers will grill him about Libra, the global currency and payments network the company announced in June as well as issues relating to allegations of advertising discrimination on its platform. The hearing comes at a pivotal time for the Libra project; earlier this month, several early partners dropped out of the effort[4], including payments and finance firms Visa, Mastercard, and PayPal. Shortly thereafter, the remaining members of the Libra Association — the consortium of 21 firms that will govern the network and currency — met to formalize the organization's council, elect a board of directors, and appoint members of its executive team. The move indicated that the plan was moving full steam ahead despite heavy scrutiny from lawmakers and the exit of several key founding members. In her opening remarks, Chairwoman of the committee and Congresswoman Maxine Waters (D-CA) once again called for a moratorium on the project until Congress can examine the issues that come with a large tech firm like Facebook being involved in the development of a digital currency. Waters urged Facebook to fix the company's problems before expanding into a new industry — highlighting issues ranging from a lack of diversity in Facebook's leadership to its failure to protect consumer data. She also criticized the company's decision not to fact-check political ads, saying that it could lead to voter suppression. "Your claim to promote freedom of speech does not ring true," Waters said, adding that it seems like Zuckerberg believes he's above the law and that such concerns raise a "serious discussion"about whether Facebook should be broken up.Youtube Embed: //www.youtube.com/embed/isTB1Bpl9SA Width: 560px Height: 315pxZuckerberg's opening testimonyIn his opening testimony, which was made public on Tuesday, Zuckerberg said his company would not participate in rolling out Libra until all regulation concerns have been met. Waters pressed Facebook executive David Marcus on this point during a previous hearing back in July, and did not interpret his answer as a commitment back then. "Facebook will not be a part of launching the Libra payments system anywhere in the world unless all US regulators approve it," Zuckerberg says in his opening remarks. "And we support Libra delaying its launch until it has fully addressed US regulatory concerns." Lawmakers and critics have expressed concern about Facebook's involvement in the financial system for a number of reasons: the blunders it has made when handling the personal data of its social network's members in the past, its sheer size and scale — which lawmakers worry could enable Libra to grow too quickly to properly manage — and the potential risk for the system being used by criminals or to finance terrorism. "I believe this is something that needs to get built, and I understand we're not the ideal messenger right now," he said. "We've faced a lot of issues over the past few years, and I'm sure people wish it was anyone but Facebook putting this idea forward." The Facebook CEO reiterated that his company will not be leading the project moving forward — that task now rests with the recently formalized Libra Association — adding that the organization is currently talking with elected officials in Congress. He also said that any payments processed through Facebook or its subsidiaries — including any eventual Libra-based transactions or those that occur through Instagram Shopping and Facebook Messenger today — are subject to "comprehensive anti-money laundering, counterterrorist financing, and sanctions monitoring." There have also been concerns about whether companies like Facebook should be involved in the financial system at all, especially considering the bubbling antitrust related tensions that have surrounded firms like Facebook, Amazon, Google, and Amazon in recent months. A draft bill called the "Keep Big Tech Out of Finance Act" was also discussed at the July hearing, which would prevent a platform company like Facebook from becoming a registered financial institution in the United States. In his testimony, Zuckerberg addressed this point as well. "Monetary policy is in the province of central banks, not Libra," Zuckerberg's testimony says. "The Libra Association has no intention of competing with any sovereign currencies or entering the monetary policy arena. . .We expect the regulatory framework for the Libra Association will ensure that the Association cannot interfere with monetary policy." Zuckerberg also provided more insight about why Facebook is becoming involved in a project like Libra at all. During his prepared testimony, he said that a project like Libra could be critical for ensuring that the United States maintains its positional as a leader in finance and doesn't get left behind as other global powers like China push ahead. "While we debate these issues, the rest of the world isn't waiting," Zuckerberg says in his testimony. "China is moving quickly to launch similar ideas in the coming months. Libra will be backed mostly by dollars and I believe it will extend America's financial leadership as well as our democratic values and oversight around the world. If America doesn't innovate, our financial leadership is not guaranteed." But Libra isn't the only subject the committee is seeking answers on. The hearing is being held to discuss Facebook's impact on the housing sector as well, coming after the Department of Housing and Urban Development filed a claim in March[5] alleging that Facebook was "encouraging, enabling, and causing housing discrimination" by allowing would-be landlords to restrict who could see housing ads on the basis of race, color, sex, familial status, and other factors. Zuckerberg recapped the changes Facebook has made to its ad platform to prevent such abuse, including requiring that advertisers go through an ads-purchasing process that prohibits targeting by age, gender or zip code. "This has been a challenging few years for Facebook," Zuckerberg said at the end of his opening remarks. "I know we have a lot to do, but I also know that the problem of financial under-inclusion is solvable, and I believe that we can play a role in helping to find the solution." Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5VPG-4981-F03R-N1X8-00000-00Livestreamed massacre means it's time to shut down Facebook Live2019-03-21T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:07:53ZLexisNexisLivestreamed massacre means it's time to shut down Facebook Liveilene

Mar 21, 2019( Phil's Stock World: http://www.philstockworld.com Delivered by Newstex) Livestreamed massacre means it's time to shut down Facebook Live Facebook Live can be fun - or really scary. I'm friday/Shutterstock.com[1] Courtesy ofJennifer Grygiel[2], Syracuse University[3] When word broke that the massacre in New Zealand was livestreamed on Facebook, I immediately thought of Robert Godwin Sr.[4] In 2017, Godwin was murdered in Cleveland, Ohio, and initial reports indicated that the attacker streamed it on Facebook Live, at the time a relatively new feature[5] of the social network. Facebook later clarified that the graphic video was uploaded after the event[6], but the incident called public attention to the risks of livestreaming violence. In the wake of Godwin's murder, I recommended that Facebook Live broadcasts be time-delayed[7], at least for Facebook users who had told the company they were under 18. That way, adult users would have an opportunity to flag inappropriate content before children were exposed to it.

Facebook Live has broadcast killings[8], as well as other serious crimes such as sexual assault, torture and child abuse[9]. Though the company has hired more than 3,000 additional human content moderators[10], Facebook is not any better at keeping horrifying violence from streaming live online without any filter or warning for users. In the 24 hours after the New Zealand massacre, 1.5 million videos and images of the killings[11] were uploaded to Facebook's servers, the company announced. Facebook highlighted the fact that 1.2 million of them 'were blocked at upload[12].' However, as a social media researcher and educator[13], I heard that as an admission that 300,000 videos and images of a mass murder passed through its automated systems and were visible on the platform. The company recently issued some analytic details and noted that fewer than 200 people viewed[14] the livestream of the massacre, and that surprisingly, no users reported it to Facebook until after it ended. These details make painfully clear how dependent Facebook is on users to flag harmful content. They also suggest that people don't know how to report inappropriate content - or don't have confidence the company will act on the complaint. The video that remained after the livestream ended was viewed nearly 4,000 times - which doesn't include copies of the video[15] uploaded to other sites and to Facebook by other users. It's unclear how many of the people who saw it were minors; youth as young as 13 are allowed to set up Facebook accounts and could have encountered unfiltered footage of murderous hatred. It's past time for the company to step up and fulfill the promise its founder and CEO, Mark Zuckerberg, made two years ago, after Godwin's murder: 'We will keep doing all we can to prevent tragedies like this from happening[16].' Play Video[17] Facebook founder and CEO Mark Zuckerberg discusses the murder of Robert Godwin Sr. A simple time-delay In the television industry, short time-delays of a few seconds are typical[18] during broadcasts of live events. That time allows a moderator to review the content and confirm that it's appropriate for a broad audience. Facebook relies on users as moderators, and some livestreams may not have a large audience like TV, so its delay would need to be longer, perhaps a few minutes. Only then would enough adult users have screened it and had the chance to report its content. Major users, including publishers and corporations, could be permitted to livestream directly after completing a training course. Facebook could even let people request a company moderator[19] for upcoming livestreams. Facebook has not yet taken this relatively simple step - and the reason is clear. Time-delays took hold in TV only because broadcasting regulators penalized broadcasters[20] for airing inappropriate content during live shows. There is effectively no regulation[21] for social media companies; they change only in pursuit of profits[22] or to minimize public outcry[23]. Whether and how to regulate social media is a political question, but many U.S. politicians have developed deep ties with platforms like Facebook[24]. Some have relied on social media to collect donations, target supporters with advertising and help them get elected[25]. Once in office, they continue to use social media to communicate with supporters[26] in hopes of getting reelected. Federal agencies also use social media to communicate with the public and influence people's opinions[27] - even in violation of U.S. law[28]. In my view, Facebook's role as a tool to gain, keep and spread political power makes politicians far less likely to rein it in. US regulation isn't coming soon Congress has not yet taken any meaningful action to regulate social media companies. Despite strong statements from politicians and even calls for hearings about social media in response to the New Zealand attack[29], U.S. regulators aren't likely to lead the way. European Union officials[30] are handling much of the work, especially around privacy[31]. New Zealand's government has stepped up, too, banning the livestream video[32] of the mosque massacre, meaning anyone who shares it could face up to NZ$10,000 in fines and 14 years in prison[33]. At least two people have already been arrested[34] for sharing it online[35]. Facebook could - and should - act now Much of the discussion about regulating social media has considered using anti-trust and monopoly laws[36] to force the enormous technology giants like Facebook to break up into smaller separate companies. But if it happens at all, that will be very difficult - breaking up AT...asted a decade[37], from the 1974 lawsuit to the 1984 launch of the 'Baby Bell' companies. In the interim, there will be many more dangerous and violent incidents people will try to livestream. Facebook should evaluate its products' potential for misuse[38] and discontinue them if the effects are harmful to society. No child should ever see the sort of 'raw and visceral content[39]' that has been produced on Facebook Live - including mass murder. I don't think adult users should be exposed to witnessing such heinous acts either, as studies have shown that viewing graphic violence has health risks[40], such as post-traumatic stress. That's why I'm no longer recommending just a livestream delay for adolescent users - it was an appeal to protect children, when more major platform changes are unlikely. But all people deserve better and safe social media. I'm now calling on Mark Zuckerberg to shut down Facebook Live in the interest of public health and safety. In my view, that feature should be restored only if the company can prove to the public - and to regulators - that its design is safer. Handling livestreaming safely includes having more than enough professional content moderators to handle the workload. Those workers also must have appropriate access to mental health support[41] and safe working environments, so that even Facebook employees and contractors are not unduly scarred by brutal violence posted online. Jennifer Grygiel[42], Assistant Professor of Communications (Social Media) ...gazine, Syracuse University[43] This article is republished from The Conversation[44] under a Creative Commons license. urn:contentItem:5VPG-4981-F03R-N1S0-00000-00Livestreamed massacre means it's time to shut down Facebook Live2019-03-21T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:07:53ZLexisNexisLivestreamed massacre means it's time to shut down Facebook LiveGuest Voice

Mar 21, 2019( The Moderate Voice: http://www.themoderatevoice.com/ Delivered by Newstex) Facebook Live can be fun - or really scary. I'm friday/Shutterstock.com[1] Jennifer Grygiel[2], Syracuse University[3] When word broke that the massacre in New Zealand was livestreamed on Facebook, I immediately thought of Robert Godwin Sr.[4] In 2017, Godwin was murdered in Cleveland, Ohio, and initial reports indicated that the attacker streamed it on Facebook Live, at the time a relatively new feature[5] of the social network. Facebook later clarified that the graphic video was uploaded after the event[6], but the incident called public attention to the risks of livestreaming violence. In the wake of Godwin's murder, I recommended that Facebook Live broadcasts be time-delayed[7], at least for Facebook users who had told the company they were under 18. That way, adult users would have an opportunity to flag inappropriate content before children were exposed to it.

Facebook Live has broadcast killings[8], as well as other serious crimes such as sexual assault, torture and child abuse[9]. Though the company has hired more than 3,000 additional human content moderators[10], Facebook is not any better at keeping horrifying violence from streaming live online without any filter or warning for users. In the 24 hours after the New Zealand massacre, 1.5 million videos and images of the killings[11] were uploaded to Facebook's servers, the company announced. Facebook highlighted the fact that 1.2 million of them 'were blocked at upload[12].' However, as a social media researcher and educator[13], I heard that as an admission that 300,000 videos and images of a mass murder passed through its automated systems and were visible on the platform. The company recently issued some analytic details and noted that fewer than 200 people viewed[14] the livestream of the massacre, and that surprisingly, no users reported it to Facebook until after it ended. These details make painfully clear how dependent Facebook is on users to flag harmful content. They also suggest that people don't know how to report inappropriate content - or don't have confidence the company will act on the complaint. The video that remained after the livestream ended was viewed nearly 4,000 times - which doesn't include copies of the video[15] uploaded to other sites and to Facebook by other users. It's unclear how many of the people who saw it were minors; youth as young as 13 are allowed to set up Facebook accounts and could have encountered unfiltered footage of murderous hatred. It's past time for the company to step up and fulfill the promise its founder and CEO, Mark Zuckerberg, made two years ago, after Godwin's murder: 'We will keep doing all we can to prevent tragedies like this from happening[16].'[embedded content]Facebook founder and CEO Mark Zuckerberg discusses the murder of Robert Godwin Sr. A simple time-delayIn the television industry, short time-delays of a few seconds are typical[17] during broadcasts of live events. That time allows a moderator to review the content and confirm that it's appropriate for a broad audience. Facebook relies on users as moderators, and some livestreams may not have a large audience like TV, so its delay would need to be longer, perhaps a few minutes. Only then would enough adult users have screened it and had the chance to report its content. Major users, including publishers and corporations, could be permitted to livestream directly after completing a training course. Facebook could even let people request a company moderator[18] for upcoming livestreams. Facebook has not yet taken this relatively simple step - and the reason is clear. Time-delays took hold in TV only because broadcasting regulators penalized broadcasters[19] for airing inappropriate content during live shows. There is effectively no regulation[20] for social media companies; they change only in pursuit of profits[21] or to minimize public outcry[22]. Whether and how to regulate social media is a political question, but many U.S. politicians have developed deep ties with platforms like Facebook[23]. Some have relied on social media to collect donations, target supporters with advertising and help them get elected[24]. Once in office, they continue to use social media to communicate with supporters[25] in hopes of getting reelected. Federal agencies also use social media to communicate with the public and influence people's opinions[26] - even in violation of U.S. law[27]. In my view, Facebook's role as a tool to gain, keep and spread political power makes politicians far less likely to rein it in.US regulation isn't coming soonCongress has not yet taken any meaningful action to regulate social media companies. Despite strong statements from politicians and even calls for hearings about social media in response to the New Zealand attack[28], U.S. regulators aren't likely to lead the way. European Union officials[29] are handling much of the work, especially around privacy[30]. New Zealand's government has stepped up, too, banning the livestream video[31] of the mosque massacre, meaning anyone who shares it could face up to NZ$10,000 in fines and 14 years in prison[32]. At least two people have already been arrested[33] for sharing it online[34].Facebook could - and should - act nowMuch of the discussion about regulating social media has considered using anti-trust and monopoly laws[35] to force the enormous technology giants like Facebook to break up into smaller separate companies. But if it happens at all, that will be very difficult - breaking up AT...asted a decade[36], from the 1974 lawsuit to the 1984 launch of the 'Baby Bell' companies. In the interim, there will be many more dangerous and violent incidents people will try to livestream. Facebook should evaluate its products' potential for misuse[37] and discontinue them if the effects are harmful to society. No child should ever see the sort of 'raw and visceral content[38]' that has been produced on Facebook Live - including mass murder. I don't think adult users should be exposed to witnessing such heinous acts either, as studies have shown that viewing graphic violence has health risks[39], such as post-traumatic stress. That's why I'm no longer recommending just a livestream delay for adolescent users - it was an appeal to protect children, when more major platform changes are unlikely. But all people deserve better and safe social media. I'm now calling on Mark Zuckerberg to shut down Facebook Live in the interest of public health and safety. In my view, that feature should be restored only if the company can prove to the public - and to regulators - that its design is safer. Handling livestreaming safely includes having more than enough professional content moderators to handle the workload. Those workers also must have appropriate access to mental health support[40] and safe working environments, so that even Facebook employees and contractors are not unduly scarred by brutal violence posted online. Jennifer Grygiel[41], Assistant Professor of Communications (Social Media) ...gazine, Syracuse University[42] This article is republished from The Conversation[43] under a Creative Commons license. Read the original article[44]. Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:42PG-S4M0-010B-S4RW-00000-00LIVING IN LIMBO2001-03-01T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:07:53ZLexisNexisPg. 54-56.58LIVING IN LIMBOHarbert, Tam

US passed legislation extending H1B visa cap from 115,000/yr to 195,000/yr for FY01-FY03 discusses provisions for H1B immigrants awaiting green cards and number of H1B immigrants who received extensions

Harbert, Tam

H1B immigrants ask: Should I stay or should I go?

THE FATE OF MURALI KRISHNA DEVARAKONDA, an H1B visa holder from India, and many more like him, was riding on legislation passed by the U.S. Congress Oct. 17, 2000. The extension of his H1B visa was due to expire about two weeks later, on Nov. 3, 2000. But his attention was not focused where most of high-tech's was--on whether the caps on H1B visas would be raised--but on other lesser known provisions included in the bill. These details would determine whether he could legally remain in this country with his wife, another H1B holder.

"The clock was running out on me," says Devarakonda. "If the law hadn't passed, I would've had to leave the country."

Luckily for him and other Indian immigrants, he'll be able to stay for at least another year. The high-tech industry and H1B visa holders were thrilled with legislation passed last fall that increases the cap on the number of H1B visas from 115,000 to 195,000 annually for fiscal years 2001, 2002 and 2003. But little mention was made of some other provisions of the law designed to help existing H1B immigrants maintain legal status while awaiting green cards.

Among the provisions included in the new law are extending the time H1B holders can stay if they meet certain qualifications, expanding the number of green cards available to H1B holders and allowing H1B holders to change jobs without losing their place in the queue for receiving a green card. Without these changes, more than 300,000 H1B holders would be forced to leave the country by 2003, according to Shailesh Gala, president of the Immigrants Support Network, Budd Lake, NJ.

"Not everything has been solved, but this is a major, major step," says Devarakonda, a senior consultant at ShaktiSoft Inc., a software company in Fremont, CA, and a board member of the Immigrants Support Network.

Never-ending backlog

But what the new law doesn't fully address is a growing backlog of H1B immigrants who are awaiting green cards. That number far exceeds the 140,000 green cards available to H1B immigrants each year. And, until the latest legislation, no one country was allowed more than 7% of that total. Since the H1B program was created, there has been a steady stream of immigrants moving to the United States to fill high-tech positions. The initial H1B visa allows the worker to stay for three years, but it is typically extended to six years. There are now roughly 420,000 H1B immigrants in the United States, according to Rick Swartz, president of Swartz & Associates Inc., a political consulting company in Washington, DC. Other estimates put the number as high as 460,000. Now that the country will allow 195,000 new H1B holders in each year, by 2003 there will probably be at least 1 million H1B holders here. But that's assuming the U.S. Immigration and Naturalization Service (INS) doesn't force some of them to return to their native countries. Does this make sense for the high-tech industry?

"It's fool-hearty to take the best and brightest," and then send them home after six years, says Swartz, a lawyer who has championed immigration, civil and human rights for more than 25 years. His consultancy does not lobby, per se, but rather helps groups to organize effectively so that they can do their own lobbying.

Swartz helped the Immigrants Support Network get started in November 1998. The group had a membership of 6,000 to 7,000, "but they had no presence in Washington," he says. The group was founded at least partly in reaction to the H1B legislation passed that year that raised the caps to 115,000 but did nothing to help current H1B holders attain green cards faster. The group was frustrated that the INS' processing of green cards, which used to take one to two years, was no taking, in many cases, as long as five years, says Gala. As the cap on the level of H1B cards has been raised, the agency has been overwhelmed by the number of people applying for green cards. There are some 900,000 immigrants currently awaiting green cards, although the INS doesn't break out the number for H1B holders, specifically, according to Eyleen Schmidt, an INS spokeswoman. The problem was that immigrants' H1B visas were expiring before they were granted green cards, and thus they were being forced to leave the country.

Swartz helped the group organize, plan their political strategy and build their membership. He helped them get their proposals included in la t year's H1B legislation.

Lives on hold

"Your life is basically on hold in a filing cabinet somewhere at the INS," says Gala, who works for Comprehensive Designers Inc., a consulting company in Budd Lake, NJ. He came to the States on an H1B visa in May 1995. In October 1996, he applied for a green card. Because of the long bureaucratic delays and the backlog at various agencies, including the Labor Department and the INS, he still does not have it and doesn't know when he will. "It's been a long four and a half years," he says.

The problem is the worst for H1B visa holders from India. They make up more than 43% of all H1B holders. The INS is allowed to grant up to 140,000 green cards to all employment-based visa holders each year. However, until last fall's legislation passed, only 7%, or 9,800 green cards, of the total could go to immigrants from any one country, whether it be India or Luxembourg.

But even with the new legislation, a bigger and more difficult problem looms: implementation. The Department of Labor and the INS re infamously slow in implementing regulations. For example, the DOL just recently issued regulations implementing the H1B legislation passed back in 1998, which raised the cap from 65,000 to 115,000, says Sheela Murthy, managing attorney at the law firm of Sheela Murthy P.C., Owings Mills, MD, which specializes in immigration law. (Murthy, herself a native of India, went through the H1B and green card process, becoming a U.S. citizen in 1998.) And the regulations that the DOL issued to implement the 1998 legislation seem in some instances a direct contradiction to the October 2000 legislation, she notes. For example, the 1998 legislation said nothing about companies that were involved with mergers and acquisitions, but the DOL regs say that the new entity must assume all responsibility for meeting the H1B requirements. In contrast, the 2000 legislation states that the new entity does not bear this responsibility. So, which guidance are immigration lawyers and their clients supposed to follow? "We're really not sure anymore," says Murthy.

The INS is even pernicious in its approach, say some. For example, the legislation increased the filing fee for an H1B visa from $610 to $1,110, and that was implemented in December. Yet, as of mid-January, it still had not come out with clear plans to implement the other parts of the law, says Gala. "It is partial in the way it is implementing these regulations," he says. What's more, immigration proponents don't like the early signs of how the INS is interpreting the new legislation. For example, the INS could interpret the law to mean that its provisions apply only to those immigrants who've filed for a green card on or after the date legislation was passed--Oct. 17, 2000. If that's true, then "that doesn't help the 300,000 that have been waiting all this time, says Gala.

INS Spokeswoman Eyleen Schmidt says that's not true. The agency's understanding is that the provisions of the law apply to all H1B holders, regardless of when they applied.

More work, not much more funding

Although management at DOL and INS has been criticized for many of the delays, it's not entirely the bureaucracies' fault. Already short of funds and unable to keep up with current applications, the agencies were not granted much in additional funding to handle the huge increase in the visa caps. The 1998 legislation added an additional $500 to the $110 H1B application filing fee, most of which was to go to the DOL to fund training programs in high tech for U.S. workers. Only 1% of that fee was set aside to help the INS handle the increase in applications and processing. In last year's legislation, that fee was raised to $1,110, and 4% was directed to help the INS handle the increase. Is that adequate? "We're hoping," says Schmidt. She says the money will be used to improve the agency's computer system, hire more people to process applications, and perhaps develop a system whereby applications could be handled electronically.

However, given the change in administration, it's doubtful that any of these changes will be enacted swiftly. For example, one of the first things the Bush Administration did was put a 60-day freeze on implementing any new regulations, says Schmidt. Add that to the historically slow pace of these agencies, and the possibility that the new administration might want to make changes, and it's anyone's guess when and in what form these regulations will come out.

What's more, there are no politically powerful folks pushing for a reform of the system. There is no consensus among high-tech companies to push for it, says Swartz. Some companies "get it," he says, while he believes that other companies may want to keep the program as is in order to keep their foreign employees "under their thumb." Although the Immigrants Support Network's leadership has talked to some high-tech companies and found that some support its goals in theory, no company has come forth with financial support for the group, says Swartz.

They should, he says. After all, these reforms are in the best interests of U.S. companies, too, which should want to keep these workers after they've invested the time, energy and money in training them. Although Intel Corp. has not lost any of its H1Bs due to the delays, it has had to send several of them back overseas to await processing, according to Jennifer Verdery, a government relations representative for Intel in Washington, DC. That's an expense most companies would want to avoid.

Cautious lobbying

But lobbyists know that the best way to attain success is to focus on just one issue, notes Swartz--in this case it was raising the cap on the number of visas. Companies also tend to focus on their short-term needs rather than long-term, complicated problems, he adds. In addition, immigration is such a controversial issue that pressing for this kind of reform would raise the ire of anti-immigration forces in Congress, such as Lamar Smith, R-TX, chairman of the House Immigration Subcommittee, who could have torpedoed the entire law.

High-tech lobbyists admit as much. "Some of these guys are under the impression we can wave a magic wand and make this problem go away," says one lobbyist. "The DOL and INS are simply hopelessly overwhelmed."

Thom Stohler, director of workforce policy at the American Electronics Association, Washington, DC, thinks the new law goes a long way to alleviate the problems of H1B holders. And the tech industry would like to push for broader immigration reform--"the country is not going to suffer if we are overrun by smart people... high-tech companies hire H1Bs because they want them and they want to keep them," he says. However, the broader reform "will be a huge process that will involve many people and will be quite messy, politically," Stohler adds. "This is going to be a highly controversial issue," especially if the economy turns south, he notes.

What's more, some high-tech lobbyists aren't sure they need to press on this issue. The Information Technology Association of America holds that there is only a small percentage of H1B workers--perhaps only 25%--that go on to get green cards, says Harris Miller, president of the Arlington, VA-based trade group. He's not heard much on the issue from his members, and so the ITAA isn't making immigration reform a big issue on its agenda. In addition, "to assume that the policy agendas of the H1B holders and their employers are congruent is not a safe assumption," he points out.

Without the big, tech-company lobby, there's little pressure to do anything. "[The Immigrant Support Network] has virtually no capacity to continue lobbying the INS to implement the regulations fairly," says Swartz. According to Gala, the immigration group's budget last year was $80,000, derived primarily from contributions of members.

In addition, it's hard to lobby support for a group whose members are not even U.S. citizens. "But we are taxpayers," notes Gala. He estimates that H1B holders pay about $400 million in taxes a year.

Impossible wish list?

What additional reforms does th Immigrants Support Network, which now has almost 20,000 members, want?

* Immigration law should be simplified and clarified. The U.S. government should decide whether it wants H1B immigrants to stay only for a limited time, or if it wants them to become permanent then it should give the green cards promptly, says Gala. "Tell us one way or the other, but don't leave us in this hanging state," he says. He believes that an immigrant who has worked in this country for four years should automatically receive a green card.

* H1B holders still are not allowed to leave the country without permission from the INS, called "advanced parole," says Devarakonda. is permission can take months to get. "What if somebody dies back in India?" he asks. The group would like to eliminate this restriction.

* The group also wants to work with the DOL and INS so that the regulations are implemented fairly and thus help solve the problems they were intended by Congress to solve.

The group could file a class-action lawsuit. "This is available to us, but we don't want to do that," says Gala. In general, says Devarakonda, the group's aim is to get rid of all the bureaucratic hurdles and delays that deny immigrants any control over their future, or even any certainty of their future options in life. Today, that control is in the hands of employers and th INS.

"The umbilical cord has to be broken," he says. "We've done nothing wrong. We come here as highly qualified professionals, but our legal status is not in our hands."

Tam Harbert is ELECTRONIC BUSINESS' national editor in Washington, DC.

H1B PETITIONS APPROVED BY COUNTRY OF BIRTHOctober 1999 to February 2000CountryTotal% of totalIndia34,38143China7,98710Canada3,1434United Kingdom2,5983SOURCE:U.S.IMMIGRATION AND NATURALIZATION SERVICE

Should they stay or should they go?

THE H1B VISA PROGRAM remains a political lightening rod that sparks debate. On the one side are high-tech companies, arguing that the program is critical if they are to find qualified workers to keep their companies running. On the other side are groups like American Engineering Association, Fort Worth, TX, who charge that companies simply use the H1B program as a way to import cheap labor rather than hiring older, more expensive American programmers.

There has been fraud in the H1B program, most admit, but it's generally been among the "job shops" -- consulting companies that farm out H1B workers to tech companies, says Rick Swartz, president of Swartz & Associates Inc. "As a category, I look at them as the bad apples" of the H1B program, he says.

As for holding wages down, a recent National Research Council report found that the H1B program is "large enough to exert a non-negligible moderating force that keeps wages from rising as fast as might be expected in a tight labor marker." Although there have been episodes in which H1B visa holders have been exploited, those cases are not the norm, says MuraliKrishna Devarakonda, a Java programmer here on an H1B visa. Some employers may pay H1Bs less than the prevailing wage, he says, but he doesn't blame them. "It's a capitalistic system," he says. "When was the last time you got a raise from your employer without asking for it?"

The problem is part cultural, Devarakonda explains. Indians are taught to be humble. "We don't know how to beat our [own] drum," he says. "Employers exploit anyone who is shy or can't negotiate well for themselves." Until the recent legislation, employers could use an H1B holder's tentative green card status to hold him hostage, but, now, under certain conditions, that's no longer true.

If there is exploitation, Devarakonda believes it can be eliminated by further reform of the H1B program. "The system is exploitative. It's not the employer or the government that's exploitative," he says. "Let's end the debate over whether employers are exploiting H1Bs. Let's get rid of any incentive to exploit." By that he means simply allowing highly qualified professionals from outside the United States to come in, based on their merits, and apply for jobs. If the immigrant gets the job, fine. If not, he will go back home.

Swartz believes immigration is good for the U.S. economy. "The lifeblood of America is new immigrants," he says. "In a global economy ... the story of America is becoming more and more the story of immigration," he believes. "The H1B story is part of a bigger story about the future of America," he adds.

The rocky road to a green card

HERE ARE THE TYPICAL STEPS immigrants and their employers take to get H1B visas,  according to Sheela Murthy, managing attorney at Sheela Murthy P.C., a law firm in Owings Mills, MD, that specializes in immigration law, and an INS spokeswoman Eyleen Schmidt.

1 The employer files with the Department of Labor (DOL) for Labor Certification on behalf of the employee. The application must provide documentation showing that the employer cannot fill the job with a permanent resident and that it will pay the "prevailing wage" for the job to be filled by the immigrant. Under U.S. law, this process should take no more than seven business days, but it sometimes takes as long as two months, according to Murthy.

2 Once the application is approved by DOL, the employer files an H1B application and fees (now $1,110) with its regional INS office. The application typically sits at the INS office from three to six months, notes Murthy. The employer or employee can pay an additional $1,000 "expedition fee," but no time frame for expedition has been set by the INS. "There is zero accountability for this," says Murthy.

3 If the three-year H1B application is approved, the employee has typically already used at least six months of the three years getting the paperwork filed to come into the country.

The cost of this process including application fees, legal fees and, if the H1B applicant is not a graduate of a U.S. university, something called a "credentials evaluation fee," can run up to $5,000, notes Murthy. Although the DOL says that the employer should pay all fees, in reality the employer often requires the applicant to pay, she says.

TOP USERS OF H1B VISASOctober 1999 to February 2000CompanyNumberMotorola Inc.618Oracle Corp.455Cisco Systems Inc.398IGate Capital Corp.(formerly Mastech Corp.)389Intel Corp.367Microsoft Corp.362SOURCE: U.S IMMIGRATION AND NATURALIZATION SERVICE

PROVISIONS OF THE 2000 H1B LAW:

*  Raises the cap on H1B visas from 115,000 to 195,000 per year for fiscal years 2001, 2002 and 2003. After that the cap is scheduled to fall back to 65,000.

* Increases fee from $610 to $1,110 per H1B application.

*  Allows extension of H1B visa beyond six years (on a year-by-year basis) if the holder is in the final stage of the green-card application process, called "adjustment of status." This process is supposed to take no more than 90 days, but is now taking 18 months to three years, according to H1B holders.

* Provides for more job mobility for H1B visa holders. If a visa holder meets the qualifications described above, and he or she has been in the "adjustment of status" stage for at least six months, the worker will not lose that status if he or she loses or changes his or her job. (Previously, the visa holder would lose his or her status and have to start the process all over.)

SOURCE: U.S. IMMIGRATION AND NATURALIZATION SERVICE AND ELECTRONIC BUSINESS

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5536-0NC1-JCC9-V26B-00000-00Living the high life2012-03-02T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:07:53ZLexisNexisFEATURESPg. 46,47Living the high lifeJAMES ELLIS

SAN FRANCISCO: The city celebrates the 75th birthday of the Golden Gate Bridge this year but get out there for April 20 and you could have even more fun 'I'VE not washed these jeans for the past eight months,' says the tall, skinny Asian guy in front of me as he tugs at the denim on his pen-thin legs.

Jason Voy is not one of the admittedly many panhandlers lining the streets of San Francisco but a jeans guru at LVC, the vintage division of Levi's.

We're debating the shrink-to-fit process in their store in Union Square and the fact the latest trend in designer denim is to eschew stripping in the local laundry and to leave jeans unwashed for as long as possible. Getting a bit whiffy? Apparently sticking them in the freezer will kill off those stinky bacteria.

To wash or not is not the only question at the two Levi's stores in San Francisco. If you're wearing a pair of the most famous jeans in the world, take a look at one of your buttons. It's likely to say 'Levi Strauss & CoSF. Cal': it was here, in 1873, that a German immigrant struck gold with denim while others were prospecting for the shiny stuff in them thar hills that surround the city.

As a result, the Levi's worldwide HQ and museum are here and there's a bewildering array of special editions on offer, as well as the chance to try out innovations before they go on sale in the rest of the world. Choose from vintage unwashed 501s painstakingly copied from the styles of eight different eras, from the late 1800s to the 1960s; buy special-edition handstitched 511s; or pick up a pair of Curve ID jeans, for which women are measured in four different places to find the perfect booty fit.

Want something altered? In-house tailors will hem, taper, add or remove belt loops and even stencil your name in the jeans. And along the way, someone like Voy will be on hand to dish out pop culture titbits such as: 'See these 1966 501s? They were Bob Dylan's favourites.' Levi's sits well beside San Francisco's other icons - the Golden Gate Bridge; the tourist trolley buses that groan up and down the city's huge hills; the spooky cells of Alcatraz; and burgeoning Chinatown - but it also illustrates the rich seam of innovation that courses through the city.

Take the Academy of Sciences - the equivalent of London's Aquarium, National History Museum and Planetarium rolled into one. Its new home in Golden Gate Park is constructed from material from its old one, the 'living roof' is covered in 1.7million plants that help to cool it in the heat and the walls are packed with thousands of pairs of jeans to provide insulation. When one of its penguins lost its feathers and could no longer regulate its own temperature, the Academy constructed an outfit from an old wetsuit that saved its life.

This innovation is dotted everywhere too, from the big tech boys that make nearby Silicon Valley their working home to the delicate flavours of Jamie Oliver's favourite Chinese restaurant, Feng, and the 21st Amendment Microbrewery, where a wheat beer flavoured with watermelon has become an award-winning smash. The bizarre thing about all this innovation is that hardly anyone actually comes from San Francisco - but so many adopt the city as their own.

'You hardly ever meet people from San Francisco,' says Sonia Bercel, who recently moved from London, 'but people are passionate about living here, they love it. Everyone is an advocate of their own neighbourhood and every neighbourhood is amazing.' The attitude of these surrogate San Franciscans is also deliciously laid-back. While in New York people seem to be in such a rush to get somewhere, San Franciscans seem to know where they are going and are comfortable getting there at their own pace. There can be few places in the world where the owner of the city's leading menswear outlet, also on Union Square, takes his pet to work every day. But sartorial Wilkes 'menswear for the bold conservative' Bashford and his daschund, Duchess, open their downtown store together every morning.

IT may be that the relaxed air is a carry-over from the hippy era of the late 1960s.

'You can literally smell San Francisco on the air,' says Ady, my guide on an excellent Segway tour of the Golden Gate Park, while pointing out one of its official '50 places to make love', detailed in a book written by a jogger who fell in love with the park in the early 1980s. 'April 20 is a huge stoners' holiday here,' continues Ady. 'It comes from the fact the police call sign for someone smoking weed is "a 420".' The park was one of the focal points of the summer of love in the 1960s - though in typical San Francisco style, it all actually kicked off in January rather than June. (Perhaps they took Mark Twain's quip about the famously cold weather - 'the coldest winter I ever spent was a summer in San Francisco' - too literally.) The epicentre of hippy era was a few blocks from here in the neighbourhood known as the Haight. Among the high-end boutiques that now line the streets, you can find a throwback to those tie-dyed, acid-dropping days in a range of trippy murals and the odd smoke shop such as Pipe Dream or The Love of Ganesha - marijuana is legal with a doctor's prescription and I'm told by one local that it's not hard to find a willing quack to help out.

A little up from the corner of Haight and Ashbury streets - the ground zero of hippydom - lies either the cleverest or worst buy in San Fran real estate.

The unremarkable three-storey clapboard house at 710 Ashbury is where the Grateful Dead, the US rock band led by Jerry Garcia, set up home for two years from 1966.

As I join the steady flow of tourists queuing to get my photo taken by the gate, I think about those heady days but I can't help but wonder… just how often did the band's legendary leader wash his jeans? Virgin Holidays (Tel: 0844 557 3865. www.virginholidays.co.uk) has five nights in San Francisco at the Hotel Kabuki from £775pp. Price includes return Virgin Atlantic flights from Heathrow to San Francisco and transfers. For more information, see   www.visitcalifornia.co.uk and   www.visitusa.org.uk RUN SAN FRANCISCO San Francisco's famous fancy dress race Bay to Breakers (   www.zazzlebaytobreakers.com) recently celebrated its 100th anniversary - but you don't have to dress up like a loon to run San Francisco.

Originally from London, San Fran resident of 25 years Michael Isgar has launched SF Run Tours offering bespoke treks running around the city for around $40 an hour. You decide on the route, which can include running over the Golden Gate Bridge or down Lombard Street - the crookedest street in the world, famous for appearing in the comic car chase in the film What's Up, Doc? Isgar's commentary on the way is excellent but make sure you train before taking him on: there are 43 hills in the city and some of the streets are super steep.

www.a4interactive.com/sfruntours

Golden age: San Francisco's iconic bridge (left); the corner of Haight and Ashbury streets, focus of 1967's Summer of Love (top); a worker at Levi's (above); and Alcatraz Island, home to the infamous prison, which closed in 1963 (right)

James Ellis tours San Francisco by Segway

'You can literally smell San Francisco on the air,' says Ady, my guide on an excellent Segway tour of the Golden Gate Park, while pointing out one of its official '50 places to make love', detailed in a book written by a jogger who fell in love with the park in the early 1980s. 'April 20 is a huge stoners' holiday here,' continues Ady. 'It comes from the fact the police call sign for someone smoking weed is "a 420".'

The park was one of the focal points of the summer of love in the 1960s - though in typical San Francisco style, it all actually kicked off in January rather than June. (Perhaps they took Mark Twain's quip about the famously cold weather - 'the coldest winter I ever spent was a summer in San Francisco' - too literally.)

The epicentre of hippy era was a few blocks from here in the neighbourhood known as the Haight. Among the high-end boutiques that now line the streets, you can find a throwback to those tie-dyed, acid-dropping days in a range of trippy murals and the odd smoke shop such as Pipe Dream or The Love of Ganesha - marijuana is legal with a doctor's prescription and I'm told by one local that it's not hard to find a willing quack to help out.

A little up from the corner of Haight and Ashbury streets - the ground zero of hippydom - lies either the cleverest or worst buy in San Fran real estate.

The unremarkable three-storey clapboard house at 710 Ashbury is where the Grateful Dead, the US rock band led by Jerry Garcia, set up home for two years from 1966.

As I join the steady flow of tourists queuing to get my photo taken by the gate, I think about those heady days but I can't help but wonder… just how often did the band's legendary leader wash his jeans?

Virgin Holidays (Tel: 0844 557 3865.

www.virginholidays.co.uk) has five nights in San Francisco at the Hotel Kabuki from £775pp. Price includes return Virgin Atlantic flights from Heathrow to San Francisco and transfers. For more information, see   www.visitcalifornia.co.uk and   www.visitusa.org.uk

RUN SAN FRANCISCO

San Francisco's famous fancy dress race Bay to Breakers (www.zazzlebaytobreakers.com) recently celebrated its 100th anniversary - but you don't have to dress up like a loon to run San Francisco.

Originally from London, San Fran resident of 25 years Michael Isgar has launched SF Run Tours offering bespoke treks running around the city for around $40 an hour. You decide on the route, which can include running over the Golden Gate Bridge or down Lombard Street - the crookedest street in the world, famous for appearing in the comic car chase in the film What's Up, Doc?

Isgar's commentary on the way is excellent but make sure you train before taking him on: there are 43 hills in the city and some of the streets are super steep.

www.a4interactive.com/sfruntours

Golden age: San Francisco's iconic bridge (left); the corner of Haight and Ashbury streets, focus of 1967's Summer of Love (top); a worker at Levi's (above); and Alcatraz Island, home to the infamous prison, which closed in 1963 (right)

James Ellis tours San Francisco by Segway
