urn:contentItem:5WCR-B751-DY0W-41PT-00000-00London On Edge; Conway On Tech CEO Meeting; Syrian Jet Shot down; G.M. Rolls Into Texas; Bezos' Wealth Soars; Koepka Wins U.S. Open; Deadly2017-06-19T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:07:54ZLexisNexisLondon On Edge; Conway On Tech CEO Meeting; Syrian Jet Shot down; G.M. Rolls Into Texas; Bezos' Wealth Soars; Koepka Wins U.S. Open; DeadlyLanhamFULL TEXT

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN HOST: Welcome back. Good Monday morning everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo. And it is Monday, June 19th. Your top stories right now 8:00 a.m. on the East Coast.

Breaking news this morning, London has been targeted again at least one killed, several others injured after a man plows his van into a crowd near a mosque. Police are treating this as terrorist attack this morning.

Technology executives are descending on the White House today, top leaders in the industry set to focus on updating the government's I.T. system on the CEOs attending, Apple CEO Tim Cook, Microsoft's Satya Nadella, IBM's Ginni Rometty among others.

The agenda also top priorities, Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell is setting a July 4th deadline for a health care vote out of the Senate. Counselor to the President, Kellyanne Conway weighed in on that, push, last hour.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

KELLYANNE CONWAY, COUNSELOR TO THE PRESIDENT: But the president is forging ahead, he's in close contact with Leader McConnell on health care reform. You know, Obamacare has been a long live for over seven years. These sinking battleships turn slowly and they've got part one through the house, now the Senate will do its work.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Meanwhile, Britain is working on its exit from the European Union, the negotiations under way today, beginning today, a look at what's is ahead and at stake coming up. Blue Apron set the range for an upcoming for initial public offering, the details as the company seeks evaluation of more than $3 billion dollars, pricing 30 million shares this morning. Futures indicating a higher opening for the broader averages, technology once again leadership here, tech stocks are leading the markets with the Dow Industrials up 73 points right here, NASDAQ expected to be up better than 40 points. This right here, that's the high of the morning.

In Europe, also strength although the European indices are off of their highs, the CAC quarante in Paris is still up almost one percent, as is the DAX Index in Germany. In Asia overnight, markets finished higher with Hong Kong the best performer, up better than one percent overnight. All those coming up and this morning, joining me to talk all about it, Maslansky and Partners President, Lee Carter, Rosecliff Capital chief executive officer Mike Murphy and Diligence President, Mike Baker. Great conversation, great to have you guys here today.

MIKE BAKER. PRESIDENT AND CO-FOUNDER. DILIGENCE: Yes, great. I just want to --

LEE CARTER, PRESIDENT, MASLANSKY + PARTNERS: Great to be here.

BAKER: -- just maybe above my abilities or my pay grade, I'm loss to explain how Blue Apron is valuing at $3 billion.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

CARTER: I mean, I want to know with their attention right now.

BARTIROMO: What is it?

MIKE MURPHY, EF EXECUTIVE OFFICER, ROSECLIFF CAPITAL CHI: That will do a billion in revenue, three-billion-dollar price. It's not that far-fetched.

BARTIROMO: They say they want to price it between 15 and 17 dollars a share and 30 million shares. Do you think that -- do you think that makes sense?

MURPHY: I think it's fair, it's a company that did 800 million in revenue last year, that will do a billion in revenue this year and they're the biggest in the space. Now, Amazon and Whole Foods getting together coming in there, could mean something else, but I think this evaluation is fair.

BAKER: What's the bottom line, what are they making and what's their profit?

MURPHY: Next question, they're losing money.

BAKER: OK.

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: They are losing money but they are growing revenue and that's what you think is the base. We'll talk more about this. President Trump is meeting with some of the nation's top technology CEOs at the White House today. Adam Shapiro is at the White House right now with the preview. Adam, good morning to you.

BLAKE BURMAN, FBN WASHINGTON CORRESPONDENT: And a good morning to you, Maria. This is the inaugural meeting of the American Technology Council and the biggest names in technology will be here for several hours talking about ways to modernize the U.S. government. Let me give you some of the names that are going to arrive here very shortly. Jeff Bezos from Amazon, Safra Catz from Oracle, Tim Cook from Apple, you've got Satya Nadella from Microsoft, the CEO from IBM and of course, Eric Schmidt, chairman of Alphabet, the company we used to call Google.

They're going to be discussing ways to streamline the I.T. services in the government which in some cases 10 to 20 years behind current status of what's expected in the private sector but here's what Kellyanne Conway had to say about these CEOs coming here today.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

CONWAY: What Jared did, he invited in the five -- the five brightest tech people are five tech experts from DOD. Five from veterans affairs have said, how can we get this together? (INAUDIBLE) now we have a system in place where veterans are retreated as one single patient seamlessly.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BURMAN: You heard Kellyanne Conway refer to Jared, Jared Kushner who the president charged with overseeing a streamlining of the U.S. government but the president also signed on May 1st an executive order to modernize the U.S. government. Some of the topics the CEOs will be discussing on ways to modernize, electronic medical records, you can take anywhere from three months to six months to transfer medical records to the V.A. system, so they're going to try and streamline that, the H-1B visa program, they're going to try to eliminate fraud in that program, and then, of course, artificial intelligence focusing on machine learning as well as big data and the ways that the U.S. government can securely store data in the cloud.

A senior administration official talking to Fox Business said, here is what we can expect, "These are things that are going to require years to really make significant progress on and our systems are in some cases 10 to 20 years out of date, so we're not going to fix that in one day. But we have to start now." And now Maria is today, they will be here in the next few hours and the president will meet with them toward the end of the day. Back to you.

BARTIROMO: All right, Adam. We'll come back to you as news develops. Thank you. Adam Shapiro at the White House this morning. Turning now to London, British authorities are investigating the van attack near a mosque early this morning as possible act of terrorism. One man was found dead at the scene, although it is still unclear if that death was related to the actual attack. At least 10 others have been wounded, the driver, a 48- year-old man, he was arrested at the scene after being detained by members of the public.

Joining me right now, the director of the Heritage Foundation's Margaret Thatcher, center for freedom and former foreign policy director under Margaret Thatcher, Nile Gardiner is with us. Nile, good morning to you. Thanks for joining us.

NILE GARDINER, DIRECTOR OF MARGARET THATCHER CENTER FOR FREEDOM, HERITAGE FOUNDATION: Good morning, Maria.

BARTIROMO: Your reaction to the act of violence in London, the fourth attack in the U.K. in the last three months.

GARDINER: Yes. Yes. Another abhorrent terrorist attack on the streets of London. An act of real callous disregard for human life once again in London. Although in this particular case it seems to be the actions of one sole individual who seem to have a sort of hatred for Muslim people. And so we have a number of casualties at this time but this is certainly an act of, you know, of tremendous evil by this particular individual. And London certainly I think has been under sort of state of -- sort of siege over the past few months. This is the fourth act of terrorism on the streets of London in recent -- in recent months and I think that, you know, certainly the city is on very, very high alert but without a doubt, of course, you know, London I think is a very, very resilient city but it does face, of course, an immense, you know, threat from terrorism.

BARTIROMO: Meanwhile, almost exactly a year after Britain voted to leave its biggest market, formal negotiations on the U.K.'s exit from the European Union are getting under way today in Brussels, I guess it's six hours ahead there, the negotiation is all under way. Here's the negotiations on -- negotiators on both sides I just say at the outset of talks earlier today.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MICHEL BARNIER, EUROPEAN CHIEF NEGOTIATOR FOR BREXIT: -- our objective is clear. We must first tackle uncertainties caused by Brexit first for citizens but also for the beneficiaries of the E.U. policies and for the impact on borders.

DAVID DAVIS, SECRETARY OF STATE FOR EXITING THE EUROPEAN UNION: We will do all that we can to ensure that we deliver a deal that works in the best interests of all citizens. To that end, we're starting these negotiations in a positive and constructive tone.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Now, what are you expecting, Prime Minister Theresa May still hasn't formed a new government, so, is that affecting the talks?

GARDINER: Well, I do think we have, you know, a certain degree of stability right now in London. The prime minister has formed a minority government. She is in discussions with the democratic union as part of the DUP, the Northern Irish party in terms of a deal that will allow the British government to be able to govern effectively. So I think that, you know, the Brexit process is certainly under way, it's not going to be derailed by this recent on election and I think you are going to see a, you know, a conservative government in place delivering Brexit.

And so the negotiations kicked off today, those negotiations will last for two years through until the end of March 2019. And it's going to be an extremely tough negotiating process, there's no doubt about it but you can be certain of one thing, the British government has pledged to deliver Brexit to the British people and Britain will be out of the European Union two years from now. So there's no going back from this.

BARTIROMO: What do you think the impact is on the U.S.? And I want to get your reaction to what's going on in the U.S. given the fact that we've got such obstructionism going on, the president has communicated an agenda and yet the critics just -- are pushing back and not allowing him to execute that agenda, when it comes to health care reform awaiting on the Senate when it comes to tax reform or waiting on health care.

GARDINER: Yes. And also from the point of view of the British of course, I mean, they're very keen to strike a free trade agreement with the United States, and so those discussions really have already started. And I believe that President Trump is very strongly in favor of such an agreement with the United Kingdom as full momentum also on Capitol Hill for this. And so, I hope that, you know, we are going to see the strengthening of the special relationship over the coming years and the implementation of a -- of a free trade deal between the U.S. and the U.K. of the world's biggest fifth largest economies as soon as Britain leaves the European Union.

So I hope that this isn't derailed by all the internal politics here in Washington which frankly has been extremely sort of corrosive and, you know, the special relationship is extremely important to U.S. interests and I'd expect to see the Trump administration working very, very closely with the British government in the months and years ahead.

BARTIROMO: And what is the perception of the Trump administration in the U.K. from your standpoint?

GARDINER: Well, I think it's, you know, it's rather mixed, and certainly I think opinion polls show that President Trump isn't hugely popular in the United Kingdom at this time but the British government has struck a very pragmatic note, I think Theresa May has cultivated a very close relationship with President Trump and I think that, you know, the British government is very, very keen to work closely with the Trump administration on a wide array, but not only of course, on the trade and Brexit issues but also with regard to the transatlantic security cooperation in the face of rising Islamist threat and also in terms of defense, cooperation as well. So I think -- but -- yes.

BARTIROMO: When it comes to business, you know, the financial services industry -- the U.S. financial services industry has a real foothold in London, is that going to be part of a trade deal do you think where it will also impact services or jobs -- American jobs in London or do you expect the financial services industry to have to move lots of people to somewhere in the Eurozone like Germany?

GARDINER: Yes -- no, I expect that, you know, U.S. businesses are going to continue to thrive and prosper in the United Kingdom and London is by far Europe's biggest financial center, it's going to continue to be the center of global finance in Europe. I think that Brexit actually is going to strengthen the British economy, it's going to make London even more attractive place to do business, once the City of London is freed from the financial shackles of E.U. membership.

And the European Union has become a sort of big government driven entity which is in my view constrains the free market actually. So Britain outside of the European Union will do even better as a global financial center. So there's nothing to fear for U.S. investors and companies who operate in the United Kingdom.

BARTIROMO: All right. We'll be watching the developments, Nile. Good to have you on the program. Thank you so much.

GARDINER: My pleasure. Thank you very much, Maria.

BARTIROMO: Nile Gardiner joining us there, Heritage.

Still, to come, Blue Apron cooks up plans for a public debut, they priced the IPO this morning, they're looking at 30 million shares to go public between 105 and 17. We're taking a look in the (INAUDIBLE) delivery company and how it's pricing that stock. Then cruising to the top of the box office, Cars 3 puts Wonder Woman in the rearview mirror. How much the kid--friendly blockbuster hold in this weekend. Back in moment.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. The U.S. military shot down a Syrian government jet, Cheryl Casone with the story. Cheryl.

CHERYL CASONE, FBN CORRESPONDENT: Well -- so Maria, this happened yesterday near the ISIS stronghold of Raqqa, the Syrian warplane fired on U.S.-backed rebels and the U.S. pilot in a F-18 Super Hornet responded. This is the first time in Syria's Civil War that a U.S. pilot has struck a regime plane that marks a new tactic in this conflict. The U.S. jet took off from the USS George H.W. Bush and this incident follows a number of recent moves against the Assad Regime and Iranian-backed forces by the U.S. Military.

Well, the battle for dominance in the sky between Boeing and Airbus continues. Boeing's board has approved a super stretch version of 737 Max which is going to be five and a half feet longer and the current 737 Max 9. This will carry 52 additional passengers. Boeing says it's going to announce orders and commitments for more than 240 of these new planes later on this week. So this jet set to debut 2020 but look at this, Boeing set to add more than a dozen points in the Dow and trading starts this morning, 9:30 a.m. Eastern Time. There is the stock and the premarket.

And then finally this Blue Apron has set terms of its initial public offering with an expectation to raise up $510 million. According to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the company could offer 30 million shares for their launch and the price expected to be somewhere between 15 and 17 dollars a share. The stock will list on The New York Stock Exchange, Maria, under the ticker symbol APRN. Keeping it simple. We like it when they do that.

BARTIROMO: All right. Blue Apron will popular among millennials, young adults. Before we get to that, you want to make a comment on the Syrian jet that was shot down by U.S. military.

BAKER: Yes. This is an interesting story that people should keep their eyes on but in a remarkable example of you've got to be kidding me. Sergey Lavrov, the Russian Foreign Minister came out after we took down this jet and said that the U.S. needs to respect Syria's territorial integrity. This is Russia talking about after their troops have rolled into Georgia and they took over Crimea, there's Ukraine.

BARTIROMO: That is funny.

BAKER: Yes. And so this is the world we live in nowadays and he can get away with saying that and, you know, some people will buy into it.

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: Will that supposed to be sort of a warning shot, Russia, you know, Russia is watching what the U.S. is doing to Syria or --

BAKER: Yes. And they're -- look, they're worried, I mean, they want to prop up Assad, obviously, they got their own report there for the Black Sea Fleet. The only reason they're there is because they want to maintain their level of influence. So they look at this and they're concerned about this. Now, we did conflict with the Russians all the time on these various airstrikes and the things that are going on there. But again, the fact that Sergey Lavrov would make this comment to us and try to lecture us about territorial integrity is absurd.

BARTIROMO: I want to talk with you about that when Walid Phares joins us. That's in 10 minutes' time. We'll continue that conversation. On Blue Apron, 30 million shares -- they want to price 30 million shares between, Mike Murphy, between 15 and 17. You said this makes sense?

MURPHY: I think it makes sense. It's a company that's going to do billion dollars in revenue, they're pricing their company $3 billion and there's huge demand for this. Remember, grocery is an 800-billion-dollar industry. You just saw Whole Foods is going to be acquired on Friday by Amazon. So, yes, this is the first of the big meal boxes coming out. I think it will do very well.

CARTER: I'm curious about retention, though, on these things. I mean, there is a lot of turnover. So it can may -- can may keep up that kind of revenue moving forward.

MURPHY: I think they can, they have big gross margins because it doesn't cost them a lot to do what they're doing and I think once they're in your home, they have other opportunities to other sources of revenue just not meal in a box.

BAKER: But they're not making money.

BAKER: They're not making yet.

BARTIROMO: Not making money yet.

BAKER: Yes. Amazon didn't make money for 15 years.

MURPHY: Oh, fine. Bring that up.

urn:contentItem:5NV7-5MD1-JBHT-D4R3-00000-00London On Edge; Conway On Tech CEO Meeting; Syrian Jet Shot down; G.M. Rolls Into Texas; Bezos' Wealth Soars; Koepka Wins U.S. Open; Deadly2017-06-19T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:07:53ZLexisNexisLondon On Edge; Conway On Tech CEO Meeting; Syrian Jet Shot down; G.M. Rolls Into Texas; Bezos' Wealth Soars; Koepka Wins U.S. Open; DeadlyLanhamFULL TEXT

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN HOST: Welcome back. Good Monday morning everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo. And it is Monday, June 19th. Your top stories right now 8:00 a.m. on the East Coast.

Breaking news this morning, London has been targeted again at least one killed, several others injured after a man plows his van into a crowd near a mosque. Police are treating this as terrorist attack this morning.

Technology executives are descending on the White House today, top leaders in the industry set to focus on updating the government's I.T. system on the CEOs attending, Apple CEO Tim Cook, Microsoft's Satya Nadella, IBM's Ginni Rometty among others.

The agenda also top priorities, Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell is setting a July 4th deadline for a health care vote out of the Senate. Counselor to the President, Kellyanne Conway weighed in on that, push, last hour.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

KELLYANNE CONWAY, COUNSELOR TO THE PRESIDENT: But the president is forging ahead, he's in close contact with Leader McConnell on health care reform. You know, Obamacare has been a long live for over seven years. These sinking battleships turn slowly and they've got part one through the house, now the Senate will do its work.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Meanwhile, Britain is working on its exit from the European Union, the negotiations under way today, beginning today, a look at what's is ahead and at stake coming up. Blue Apron set the range for an upcoming for initial public offering, the details as the company seeks evaluation of more than $3 billion dollars, pricing 30 million shares this morning. Futures indicating a higher opening for the broader averages, technology once again leadership here, tech stocks are leading the markets with the Dow Industrials up 73 points right here, NASDAQ expected to be up better than 40 points. This right here, that's the high of the morning.

In Europe, also strength although the European indices are off of their highs, the CAC quarante in Paris is still up almost one percent, as is the DAX Index in Germany. In Asia overnight, markets finished higher with Hong Kong the best performer, up better than one percent overnight. All those coming up and this morning, joining me to talk all about it, Maslansky and Partners President, Lee Carter, Rosecliff Capital chief executive officer Mike Murphy and Diligence President, Mike Baker. Great conversation, great to have you guys here today.

MIKE BAKER. PRESIDENT AND CO-FOUNDER. DILIGENCE: Yes, great. I just want to --

LEE CARTER, PRESIDENT, MASLANSKY + PARTNERS: Great to be here.

BAKER: -- just maybe above my abilities or my pay grade, I'm loss to explain how Blue Apron is valuing at $3 billion.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

CARTER: I mean, I want to know with their attention right now.

BARTIROMO: What is it?

MIKE MURPHY, EF EXECUTIVE OFFICER, ROSECLIFF CAPITAL CHI: That will do a billion in revenue, three-billion-dollar price. It's not that far-fetched.

BARTIROMO: They say they want to price it between 15 and 17 dollars a share and 30 million shares. Do you think that -- do you think that makes sense?

MURPHY: I think it's fair, it's a company that did 800 million in revenue last year, that will do a billion in revenue this year and they're the biggest in the space. Now, Amazon and Whole Foods getting together coming in there, could mean something else, but I think this evaluation is fair.

BAKER: What's the bottom line, what are they making and what's their profit?

MURPHY: Next question, they're losing money.

BAKER: OK.

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: They are losing money but they are growing revenue and that's what you think is the base. We'll talk more about this. President Trump is meeting with some of the nation's top technology CEOs at the White House today. Adam Shapiro is at the White House right now with the preview. Adam, good morning to you.

BLAKE BURMAN, FBN WASHINGTON CORRESPONDENT: And a good morning to you, Maria. This is the inaugural meeting of the American Technology Council and the biggest names in technology will be here for several hours talking about ways to modernize the U.S. government. Let me give you some of the names that are going to arrive here very shortly. Jeff Bezos from Amazon, Safra Catz from Oracle, Tim Cook from Apple, you've got Satya Nadella from Microsoft, the CEO from IBM and of course, Eric Schmidt, chairman of Alphabet, the company we used to call Google.

They're going to be discussing ways to streamline the I.T. services in the government which in some cases 10 to 20 years behind current status of what's expected in the private sector but here's what Kellyanne Conway had to say about these CEOs coming here today.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

CONWAY: What Jared did, he invited in the five -- the five brightest tech people are five tech experts from DOD. Five from veterans affairs have said, how can we get this together? (INAUDIBLE) now we have a system in place where veterans are retreated as one single patient seamlessly.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BURMAN: You heard Kellyanne Conway refer to Jared, Jared Kushner who the president charged with overseeing a streamlining of the U.S. government but the president also signed on May 1st an executive order to modernize the U.S. government. Some of the topics the CEOs will be discussing on ways to modernize, electronic medical records, you can take anywhere from three months to six months to transfer medical records to the V.A. system, so they're going to try and streamline that, the H-1B visa program, they're going to try to eliminate fraud in that program, and then, of course, artificial intelligence focusing on machine learning as well as big data and the ways that the U.S. government can securely store data in the cloud.

A senior administration official talking to Fox Business said, here is what we can expect, "These are things that are going to require years to really make significant progress on and our systems are in some cases 10 to 20 years out of date, so we're not going to fix that in one day. But we have to start now." And now Maria is today, they will be here in the next few hours and the president will meet with them toward the end of the day. Back to you.

BARTIROMO: All right, Adam. We'll come back to you as news develops. Thank you. Adam Shapiro at the White House this morning. Turning now to London, British authorities are investigating the van attack near a mosque early this morning as possible act of terrorism. One man was found dead at the scene, although it is still unclear if that death was related to the actual attack. At least 10 others have been wounded, the driver, a 48- year-old man, he was arrested at the scene after being detained by members of the public.

Joining me right now, the director of the Heritage Foundation's Margaret Thatcher, center for freedom and former foreign policy director under Margaret Thatcher, Nile Gardiner is with us. Nile, good morning to you. Thanks for joining us.

NILE GARDINER, DIRECTOR OF MARGARET THATCHER CENTER FOR FREEDOM, HERITAGE FOUNDATION: Good morning, Maria.

BARTIROMO: Your reaction to the act of violence in London, the fourth attack in the U.K. in the last three months.

GARDINER: Yes. Yes. Another abhorrent terrorist attack on the streets of London. An act of real callous disregard for human life once again in London. Although in this particular case it seems to be the actions of one sole individual who seem to have a sort of hatred for Muslim people. And so we have a number of casualties at this time but this is certainly an act of, you know, of tremendous evil by this particular individual. And London certainly I think has been under sort of state of -- sort of siege over the past few months. This is the fourth act of terrorism on the streets of London in recent -- in recent months and I think that, you know, certainly the city is on very, very high alert but without a doubt, of course, you know, London I think is a very, very resilient city but it does face, of course, an immense, you know, threat from terrorism.

BARTIROMO: Meanwhile, almost exactly a year after Britain voted to leave its biggest market, formal negotiations on the U.K.'s exit from the European Union are getting under way today in Brussels, I guess it's six hours ahead there, the negotiation is all under way. Here's the negotiations on -- negotiators on both sides I just say at the outset of talks earlier today.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MICHEL BARNIER, EUROPEAN CHIEF NEGOTIATOR FOR BREXIT: -- our objective is clear. We must first tackle uncertainties caused by Brexit first for citizens but also for the beneficiaries of the E.U. policies and for the impact on borders.

DAVID DAVIS, SECRETARY OF STATE FOR EXITING THE EUROPEAN UNION: We will do all that we can to ensure that we deliver a deal that works in the best interests of all citizens. To that end, we're starting these negotiations in a positive and constructive tone.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Now, what are you expecting, Prime Minister Theresa May still hasn't formed a new government, so, is that affecting the talks?

GARDINER: Well, I do think we have, you know, a certain degree of stability right now in London. The prime minister has formed a minority government. She is in discussions with the democratic union as part of the DUP, the Northern Irish party in terms of a deal that will allow the British government to be able to govern effectively. So I think that, you know, the Brexit process is certainly under way, it's not going to be derailed by this recent on election and I think you are going to see a, you know, a conservative government in place delivering Brexit.

And so the negotiations kicked off today, those negotiations will last for two years through until the end of March 2019. And it's going to be an extremely tough negotiating process, there's no doubt about it but you can be certain of one thing, the British government has pledged to deliver Brexit to the British people and Britain will be out of the European Union two years from now. So there's no going back from this.

BARTIROMO: What do you think the impact is on the U.S.? And I want to get your reaction to what's going on in the U.S. given the fact that we've got such obstructionism going on, the president has communicated an agenda and yet the critics just -- are pushing back and not allowing him to execute that agenda, when it comes to health care reform awaiting on the Senate when it comes to tax reform or waiting on health care.

GARDINER: Yes. And also from the point of view of the British of course, I mean, they're very keen to strike a free trade agreement with the United States, and so those discussions really have already started. And I believe that President Trump is very strongly in favor of such an agreement with the United Kingdom as full momentum also on Capitol Hill for this. And so, I hope that, you know, we are going to see the strengthening of the special relationship over the coming years and the implementation of a -- of a free trade deal between the U.S. and the U.K. of the world's biggest fifth largest economies as soon as Britain leaves the European Union.

So I hope that this isn't derailed by all the internal politics here in Washington which frankly has been extremely sort of corrosive and, you know, the special relationship is extremely important to U.S. interests and I'd expect to see the Trump administration working very, very closely with the British government in the months and years ahead.

BARTIROMO: And what is the perception of the Trump administration in the U.K. from your standpoint?

GARDINER: Well, I think it's, you know, it's rather mixed, and certainly I think opinion polls show that President Trump isn't hugely popular in the United Kingdom at this time but the British government has struck a very pragmatic note, I think Theresa May has cultivated a very close relationship with President Trump and I think that, you know, the British government is very, very keen to work closely with the Trump administration on a wide array, but not only of course, on the trade and Brexit issues but also with regard to the transatlantic security cooperation in the face of rising Islamist threat and also in terms of defense, cooperation as well. So I think -- but -- yes.

BARTIROMO: When it comes to business, you know, the financial services industry -- the U.S. financial services industry has a real foothold in London, is that going to be part of a trade deal do you think where it will also impact services or jobs -- American jobs in London or do you expect the financial services industry to have to move lots of people to somewhere in the Eurozone like Germany?

GARDINER: Yes -- no, I expect that, you know, U.S. businesses are going to continue to thrive and prosper in the United Kingdom and London is by far Europe's biggest financial center, it's going to continue to be the center of global finance in Europe. I think that Brexit actually is going to strengthen the British economy, it's going to make London even more attractive place to do business, once the City of London is freed from the financial shackles of E.U. membership.

And the European Union has become a sort of big government driven entity which is in my view constrains the free market actually. So Britain outside of the European Union will do even better as a global financial center. So there's nothing to fear for U.S. investors and companies who operate in the United Kingdom.

BARTIROMO: All right. We'll be watching the developments, Nile. Good to have you on the program. Thank you so much.

GARDINER: My pleasure. Thank you very much, Maria.

BARTIROMO: Nile Gardiner joining us there, Heritage.

Still, to come, Blue Apron cooks up plans for a public debut, they priced the IPO this morning, they're looking at 30 million shares to go public between 105 and 17. We're taking a look in the (INAUDIBLE) delivery company and how it's pricing that stock. Then cruising to the top of the box office, Cars 3 puts Wonder Woman in the rearview mirror. How much the kid--friendly blockbuster hold in this weekend. Back in moment.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. The U.S. military shot down a Syrian government jet, Cheryl Casone with the story. Cheryl.

CHERYL CASONE, FBN CORRESPONDENT: Well -- so Maria, this happened yesterday near the ISIS stronghold of Raqqa, the Syrian warplane fired on U.S.-backed rebels and the U.S. pilot in a F-18 Super Hornet responded. This is the first time in Syria's Civil War that a U.S. pilot has struck a regime plane that marks a new tactic in this conflict. The U.S. jet took off from the USS George H.W. Bush and this incident follows a number of recent moves against the Assad Regime and Iranian-backed forces by the U.S. Military.

Well, the battle for dominance in the sky between Boeing and Airbus continues. Boeing's board has approved a super stretch version of 737 Max which is going to be five and a half feet longer and the current 737 Max 9. This will carry 52 additional passengers. Boeing says it's going to announce orders and commitments for more than 240 of these new planes later on this week. So this jet set to debut 2020 but look at this, Boeing set to add more than a dozen points in the Dow and trading starts this morning, 9:30 a.m. Eastern Time. There is the stock and the premarket.

And then finally this Blue Apron has set terms of its initial public offering with an expectation to raise up $510 million. According to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the company could offer 30 million shares for their launch and the price expected to be somewhere between 15 and 17 dollars a share. The stock will list on The New York Stock Exchange, Maria, under the ticker symbol APRN. Keeping it simple. We like it when they do that.

BARTIROMO: All right. Blue Apron will popular among millennials, young adults. Before we get to that, you want to make a comment on the Syrian jet that was shot down by U.S. military.

BAKER: Yes. This is an interesting story that people should keep their eyes on but in a remarkable example of you've got to be kidding me. Sergey Lavrov, the Russian Foreign Minister came out after we took down this jet and said that the U.S. needs to respect Syria's territorial integrity. This is Russia talking about after their troops have rolled into Georgia and they took over Crimea, there's Ukraine.

BARTIROMO: That is funny.

BAKER: Yes. And so this is the world we live in nowadays and he can get away with saying that and, you know, some people will buy into it.

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: Will that supposed to be sort of a warning shot, Russia, you know, Russia is watching what the U.S. is doing to Syria or --

BAKER: Yes. And they're -- look, they're worried, I mean, they want to prop up Assad, obviously, they got their own report there for the Black Sea Fleet. The only reason they're there is because they want to maintain their level of influence. So they look at this and they're concerned about this. Now, we did conflict with the Russians all the time on these various airstrikes and the things that are going on there. But again, the fact that Sergey Lavrov would make this comment to us and try to lecture us about territorial integrity is absurd.

BARTIROMO: I want to talk with you about that when Walid Phares joins us. That's in 10 minutes' time. We'll continue that conversation. On Blue Apron, 30 million shares -- they want to price 30 million shares between, Mike Murphy, between 15 and 17. You said this makes sense?

MURPHY: I think it makes sense. It's a company that's going to do billion dollars in revenue, they're pricing their company $3 billion and there's huge demand for this. Remember, grocery is an 800-billion-dollar industry. You just saw Whole Foods is going to be acquired on Friday by Amazon. So, yes, this is the first of the big meal boxes coming out. I think it will do very well.

CARTER: I'm curious about retention, though, on these things. I mean, there is a lot of turnover. So it can may -- can may keep up that kind of revenue moving forward.

MURPHY: I think they can, they have big gross margins because it doesn't cost them a lot to do what they're doing and I think once they're in your home, they have other opportunities to other sources of revenue just not meal in a box.

BAKER: But they're not making money.

BAKER: They're not making yet.

BARTIROMO: Not making money yet.

BAKER: Yes. Amazon didn't make money for 15 years.

MURPHY: Oh, fine. Bring that up.

BARTIROMO: We'll take a break. When we come back, President Trump talks tech, the biggest names in the tech industry headed to the White House today for a meeting. We are previewing Apple's Tim Cook, Amazon Jeff Bezos. Among the names looking to help upgrade the government's I.T. system. What else is on that agenda for the meeting, that's up next. General Motors, meanwhile, hiring shifts into high gear, the automaker bringing hundreds of jobs from Mexico to Texas. Why G.M. is moving back across the border. Back in a moment.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Technology giants headed to Washington today, the White House is hosting its inaugural American Technology Council Summit. Today, those attending include Amazon CEO Jeff Bezos, Apple CEO Tim Cook, IBM CEO Ginni Rometty among others. They're expected to discuss ways to modernize the government through technology.

I want to bring in DisruptDC Charlie Kolb. Charlie, good to see you. Thanks for joining the conversation. And your launching DisruptDC today, it is a nonpartisan business coalition for better government in elections. What do you hope to see from the meeting today?

CHARLIE KOLB, CEO AND PRESIDENT, DISRUPTDC: Well, first of all, I think it's a good that the president is holding this summit and here's the fact. We have the technology now to upgrade government from end-to-end, we've seen disasters in the Affordable Care Act rollout problems with the veterans administration, political campaigns being hacked, banks and even the office of personnel management being hacked. So we've got the capability to get this right. To disrupt the way business is currently been done and Harvard professor Michael Porter said that the number one thing standing in the way of greater competitiveness and economic growth is our dysfunctional government.

MURPHY: It's Mike Murphy here. I -- I'm hoping that when these business leaders meet with President Trump today, although it's important to attack how technology is going to help the government and to interact with the people, I'm hoping it kind of brings together both sides, you know, and left, right, republican, democrat and realize that working on one agenda can really advance that and it move all of us forward and then maybe move that on to tax reform or health care reform. Is there -- is that part of this? Could that -- am I being too optimistic here?

KOLB: Not in the least, I mean, this is a nonpartisan, bipartisan agenda, this is a real opportunity to make progress to cut through all the sort of political garbage here and really function -- focus on what the American people need, what our government needs in order to function. We want to see also technology applied to elections and better voting, the way public policy is made and that's the point you just raised, Mike, and then more broadly, in terms of how the government functions overall.

BAKER: Hey, Charlie, Mike Baker here, because we only have guys named Mike on the show this morning. Do you think it's really realistic to talk about something that could be done in nonpartisan, bipartisan manner in today's environment?

KOLB: Look, I'm an optimist. If you got good ideas there's a public need, I'm convinced that we can break through this. I mean, this situation now, it's unfortunate but we need leadership, bipartisan leadership, leadership from the business community and we can make a difference. I've seen it before, I ran public policy business-led, think tank for 15 years, the committee for economic development. We have an impact on campaign finance reform, early childhood education. Business is an important voice here and again, I think exactly this type of technology council here can show the American people that people can come together and get things done, we need this.

BARTIROMO: What about getting things done in terms of the agenda? I mean, you know, yesterday I spoke with Alabama Congressman Mo Brooks on Sunday Morning Futures who walked through whether or not we are going to see things like health care reform and tax reform this year. Listen to this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. MO BROOKS (R), ALABAMA: The Senate once again is empowering the Democrats to be obstructionist and to block why President Trump, why the majority of house and majority of the Senate was elected to accomplish, much of dissatisfaction of all those voters of Senate through Washington, D.C. So unless the Senate changes the way in which they operate, I'm afraid you're going to continue to see this kind of deadlock without the kind of improvements that the people sent us to Washington, D.C. to complement.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: So, Charlie, you say DisruptDC is trying to break that type of gridlock in Washington and yet, you've got all the finger-pointing going on right now. Why is the Senate sitting on the health care bill, when are we actually going to get movement on this agenda?

KOLB: Well, it's a matter of public will, I think, and also among our elected officials. Look, Maria, in 1986, Ronald Reagan forged a bipartisan working group, Senator Bill Bradley, Dan Rostenkowski and they got tax reform through. They cleared out a lot of the mess in the tax reform, it lasted for 20 some years, the barnacles have grown back, we need to do that again. So there are examples when we done it before and unfortunately, things like happened in the neighborhood not too far from my house in Alexandria, Virginia last week, show the importance of putting aside this vitriol and for people in the Congress of good will coming together and finding a way to do this. I mean, frankly, the American people want this.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

KOLB: I think they want tax reform, they want lower regulations, they want a government that works and they want growth that's greater than two percent which is just unacceptable.

BARTIROMO: Right. Well, that's why we want to see if this actually happens this year. Charlie, good to have your insights. Thanks so much.

KOLB: You're welcome. Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Charlie Kolb joining us there. We'll be watching.

Coming up. Tragedy rocks London yet again, at least one person is dead, nearly a dozen others injured after a man plows van into a crowd near a mosque in Northern London. What we know about the attacker this morning. Three -- we've got four terrorist attacks in three months in London.

Jeff Bezos surged toward the title of world's richest man continues. The Amazon founder closing in on Bill Gates after the company's deal to acquire Whole Foods. The soaring net worth still ahead.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Good Monday morning! Welcome back, everybody, thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo, and it is Monday, June 19th, your top stories right now 8:30 a.m. on the East Coast. London on edge again, this morning; at least one person has been killed, several injured after a man plows a van into a crowd near a mosque. British Prime Minister, Theresa May, calling the attack sickening the latest on the investigation, coming up.

Breaking news this morning, President Trump tweeting on the agenda just moments ago, here's what he said: "The Dems want to stop tax cuts, good healthcare, and border security. Their Obamacare is dead with 100 percent increases in premiums. Vote for Karen Handel." That, of course, he refers to the Georgia Special Election. Meanwhile, technology executives descend on the White House today. Top leaders in the industry set to focus on updating the government's I.T. Systems among the CEOs attending: Apple's Tim Cook, Microsoft's Satya Nadella, and IBM's Ginni Rometty. Counsel to the President, Kellyanne Conway, weighed in on the meeting last hour.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

CONWAY: The Chair, he didn't invite in five, the five brightest tech people or five tech experts from DOD, five from Veterans Affairs, and said how can we get this together? Voila! Now, we have a system in place where veterans will be treated as one single patient seamlessly.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Plus, Amazon CEO, Jeff Bezos, also headed to White House. He is closer to becoming the world's richest person. The Whole Food deal announcements helping him climb the ranks yesterday; his net worth soared, or last week his net worth soared all the way up above $80 million because of the movement of stock on the Whole Foods deal. General Motors moving jobs back to the U.S.; the detail as the automaker announces plans to open a new plant in Texas.

And markets are higher this morning; Futures indicating a rally at the opening of trading for the tune of 70 points on the Dow Industrial Average, 50 points on the NASDAQ composite. In Europe, this morning, also the indices are across the board up. Take a look, FTSE 100 up one-half of one percent, the CAC40 and the Dax Index both up almost one percent. And in Asia, overnight, markets finished higher. The best performer is in Hong Kong with Hang Seng Index up better than one percent. Brooks Koepka, making a name for himself at U.S. Open.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

ANNOUNCER: Koepka, a major champion

(CHEERS AND APPLAUSE)

(END VIDEO CLIP)

First, our top stories this half an hour: Britain has been rocked by a tragedy yet again. London police are investigating a possible terrorist attack outside of a mosque late last night. Investigators say that a 40- year-old man rammed a van into a crowd injuring ten people, at least. One man was found dead at the scene; it is unclear, however, if that death is related to this attack. Prime Minister, Theresa May, is planning to hold an emergency meeting on the case later today.

Joining us right now: the Wall Street Journal U.K. and Brexit Editor, Stephen Fidler. Steven, good to have you, thanks so much for joining us. I want to get to Britain exiting the E.U. in a moment, but first, this is the fourth major attack in the U.K. since March; what is your reaction?

STEPHEN FIDLER, WALL STREET JOURNAL AND BREXIT EDITOR: Well, I think it's certainly a surprise than worried people here. And I think there's an extra air of uncertainty, not only with these attacks but with the building fire last Wednesday. So, London, in particular, I think is feeling this.

BARTIROMO: Is there a feeling that things need to change in terms of security? I mean, how are people feeling in terms of why this is happening, why London has been under such attack just in the last three months or so?

FIDLER: Well, I think the - I think there is a sense that things need to change, and there is a question that obviously the security services have in terms of what they're going to do to deal with people who appear radical but don't necessarily appear set of violence, you know, what to do to stop these people going into violence. So, that's one thing; I think there'll be a lot of community policing and these kinds of things. So, I would say, you know, London has noticed this, but I was down at Borough Market despite those attacks on London Bridge a week or so ago on Friday, and the place was just teeming with people. I mean, it's a - you know, London isn't shutting down in any sense.

LEE CARTER, MASLANSKY + PARTNERS PRESIDENT: I'm curious what the political environment is like there? Here in the U.S., people say enough with the partisanship. It seems like the U.K. is having a very, very similar experience right now. And I'm just curious how people are looking at Theresa May, and is she going to be able to lead us through this?

FIDLER: I think you hit on something there. I think there is a lot of political uncertainty, particularly given what the election result was last - a couple weeks ago. In a sense that she expected to come with an increased majority; we expected to have a stronger government, and in many ways, we have a weaker one, she doesn't even have a majority in the House Commons. And it looks like she's kind of uncertain in handling a lot of these things. You know, she hasn't been very adept at adjusting to and dealing with the crisis as they've come one after the other. So, I think, you know, there is the sense of the government is, you know, not reacting to this very well, and that she, in particular, is struggling to cope with all of the things on her plate, you know, including the Brexit negotiation which is starting today.

MIKE BAKER, FORMER CENTRAL INTELLIGENCE AGENCY OPERATIVE: Stephen, you just something, I think is very important, you just referred to community policing when you talk about how we try to get ahead of the curve here. To what degree do you think the Met Police, or MI-5, or others had had or having success in developing some line of communication within the Muslim communities here in the U.K?

FIDLER: I think they've done that. Obviously, they'll be looking at what's happened and figure they haven't done it will enough, and it's one of those things that's come into the political debate here which is whether the cutbacks that have taken place in terms of government spending since the financial crisis certainly have reduced the numbers of policemen and reduced the numbers of police on the streets. So, that sends at the political debate with the Labour Party saying, you know, this is a consequence of the conservative policies that there aren't as many police on the street as they used to be in, and the community policing that used to go on five years ago or so, isn't happening to the same degree now.

BARTIROMO: Yes. We're going to be watching that. That's a really important point to bring up. Let me switch gears and ask you about talks officially underway now for Britain to leave the European Union; what are you expecting here, Stephen, in terms of David Davis-the Brexit Secretary- meeting with the E.U.'s Chief Negotiator in Brussels; that meeting happening right now. David said that you're determined to build a strong partnership. Listen to this; I want to get your reaction.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DAVID DAVIS, BREXIT SECRETARY: There's more that unites us than divides us. So, while we were ghastly to be, challenging times ahead of us in the negotiations, we will do all we can to assure that we deliver that works in the best interest of all citizens.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: And then, of course, there are concerns that Prime Minister Theresa May's government is too fragile when she the majority in the snap election two weeks ago. Their growing calls for her to drop her plan of the hard exit out of the E.U.; what are your thoughts here? How does this play out?

FIDLER: Well, it's a - I think a when Theresa May called an election in April, there was a feeling in Europe, in Brussel that, OK, we're going to have a stronger leader in the U.K. that can deliver on the promises she makes in the negotiations. So, that hasn't happened. So, I think on the other side of the, you know, from European Union perspective, there is sort of, you know, a lot questions about who they're dealing, and whether this woman is going to be in charge six months from now, and whether they should make concessions in negotiations with someone who might not be around for a very long.

And on the other hand, as you say, in the U.K., she less able to deliver on the promises, you know, because the House of Commons is divided, as some of their own party don't want the kind of hard Brexit. And you know, it's possible that the House of Commons or the House of Lords, which is the unelected second chamber could overturn a lot of what she's trying to do. So, I think we're entering these negotiations only 21 months to go before the U.K. leaves the E.U. in a very uncertain situation.

MIKE MURPHY, ROSECLIFF VENTURES FOUNDER AND MANAGING PARTNER: Stephen, it's Mike Murphy, I would think of these recent attacks that's in the U.K. that the people who are going to be voting would want to be more for Brexit, so that they could kind of control their borders, and maybe be safer as a group. Do you see that gaining any momentum kind of the pro- Brexit crowd because of the recent attacks?

FIDLER: I don't see that as a - the opinion polls don't seem to show that. I mean, there is an element of that in the discussions. I mean, you know, even in the European Union, the UK. could - you know, they're always possible controls from other people coming in for the U.K. So, it's not quite true to say the U.K. didn't control these borders. What it had an issue with was people coming into, and working in the U.K. from other parts of the European Union, and the U.K. could say, quote his answer. So, I think there's a slightly different questionnaire, and I think from the other side of the coin is the state of the British economy. I mean, the pound fell very sharply after the referendum last year. Inflation is starting to feed through, and people are fighting their standard of living being eroded. So, maybe that the sorts of an anti-Brexit crowd are kind of getting a little more growing, somewhat, because of concerns about the economy.

BAKER: Stephen, Mike Baker here again, do you feel that comment of David Davis is correct when he said that there's more that unites the U.K. with U.E. and then divides you?

FIDLER: I think there's a -- there's a sense in both - in which both sides want a good deal out of this. I don't think it's in any - nobody thinks it's in their interest, but this all blows up and that's a sort of a big break, or at least very few people think that's a - that's a great idea. So, I think that's true. I think that the thing that's left unsaid and really that the U.K. hasn't held its answer is what actually do they (INAUDIBLE) from this new relationship. And certainly, some of the things that they've outlined don't seem to be likely to be agreed on the other side. So, I think the - actually, the E.U. said much more about what it's -- how it's going to approach the negotiations than the U.K. - than the U.K. has. There are a lot of unanswered questions about what the U.K. really is looking for out of all of this.

BARTIROMO: Stephen, then new developments in France, newly elected President, Emanuel Macron consolidating power. His party obviously winning a clear majority in parliament overnight what does this victory mean for the E.U.?

FIDLER: It's interesting because it's contrast very much with what's going on in the U.K., where you have - you have a leadership that is weakened. Now, we've had this guy coming almost from nowhere in a year, creating a political movement, becoming the President of France and gaining a huge majority in the parliament to push through the kind of things that he said he wants to do, which is including reforming the French slave market. So, I think the narrative in which the U.K. went into the sort of referendum which was a declining European Union and sort of strengthening Britain. That sort of - that kind of mood music has changed because I think the -- to some extent, anyway, and I wouldn't want to exaggerate this, the E.U. has got its mojo back partly thanks to, what, some Macron who was a very pro-E.U. candidate is doing, and also the fact that Angela Merkel looks as if she's going to come back as chancellor, possibly with, you know, increased majority or an increased size of her party.

So, in a sense, you know, it looks like the E.U. is sort of moving forward to an extent that we didn't expect a year ago. I mean, Macron's problem is going to be not in the parliament now. The question is going to be, what happens in the streets? How are they going to react? The trade unions and others, how are they going to react to what he's trying to do in the labor market and to reform the economy?

BARTIROMO: Yes, that's an important point, and that obviously becomes clearer over the months and days to come. Stephen, great to get your insights. Thanks so much. Stephen Fidler joining us this morning in London.

FIDLER: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Coming up, Boeing takes flight with a new plane. How the jetliner could rub up competition against rival, Airbus. Stock has been on fire of Boeing. Then, Vice President Mike Pence ads some four-legged friends to his family. Their cute new pet social media debut, straight ahead. Back in a moment.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Markets are looking higher this morning. Take a look at Futures indicating a pretty good rally at the opening of trading. 68 points higher on the Dow Jones Industrial Average. We're watching a couple of names for you. Boeing unveiled its first new jet in four years. The company will develop a bigger 737. Boeing says 10 customers have already committed to buying that plane. The announcement coming at the Paris air show as the jetmaker looks to take on rising competition from Airbus.

We are watching the banks this morning, including JPMorgan Chase. The Federal Reserve is set to release the latest result of the stress test beginning Thursday this week. Investors are hoping that the banks will get approval to return cash to shareholders in the form of dividends. And U.S. Airlines gearing up for the possibility of an expanded ban of carryon laptops. Cheryl Casone on that detail right now. Cheryl?

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Yes, Maria, we were thinking that we might get news like this. So, that initial ban that was put into effect in May by the U.S. and the U.K. did affect some flights from the Middle East and North Africa. A ban now under consideration by the Trump administration would involve flights originating for as many as 71 airports around the world. Big expansion. That would mean additional security checks and most likely a lot of angry international customers.

Well, we're watching an extreme heat wave happening right now as out in the southwest, parts of California, Arizona, Nevada, and Utah all really suffering. Temperatures expected to climb well above 110 degrees this week in several parts of that region. Death Valley, that's the hottest place in America could see, get this, 124 degrees tomorrow. And we are told that some tourists actually finding to go there to experience Death Valley in 124 degrees. No, not a smart idea.

All right. Another headlines this morning. Good God. Wal-Mart is going shopping for an online retailer. The company - this actually went down on Friday, Maria, is buying Bonobos, they sell men's clothing for $310 million in cash. Now, this deal coming as Wal-Mart takes on Amazon for the future of retail, and of course, it's on the same date that Amazon announced the big deal, of course, to buy whole foods. Wal-Mart has been moving aggressively to try and transform himself into a major e-commerce power. They bought jet.com last year for more than $3 billion (AUDIO GAP) today as you could see on your chart under pressure, though, this morning.

And then, Vice President Mike Pence celebrated Father's Day by adding two new members to the family. The Pences welcomed a new kitten and dog into their home. The V.P.'s daughter, Charlotte, posted pictures of the new addition, Charlie and Hazel. They replaced the Pence's beagle, Maverick, who died shortly before for the election. And then (INAUDIBLE) of a cat, Oreo, who passed away earlier this month. They joined Pickles, another family cat, by the way. And they also have a bunny, Maria, named Marilyn Van Dough. They love (INAUDIBLE)

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: That's great. Marilyn, Hazel, Pickles. I love it. I love it.

CARTER: I always trust people who - I always trust people who love animals more than those that's -

BARTIROMO: Me, too. That's great.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: We are on this story, ladies and gentlemen. For all new Mike Pence pet news, you (INAUDIBLE) here.

BARTIROMO: A lot of pets. We'll take a break. When we come back, fighting crime and making a return on your investment at the same time. Why superhero comic books are trending at the auction block. We'll tell you about it, back in a minute.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. May 2017 was a win for comic books with $48.2 million worth of merchandise ordered. This after comic book sales had a 20-year sales record last August who was (INAUDIBLE) by the success of both the Marvel and D.C. Film Universes. Joining me right now is ComicConnect.com COO, Vincent Zurzolo. Good to see you. Thank you so much for being here.

VINCENT ZURZOLO, COMICCONNECT.COM CHIEF OPERATING OFFICER: Thanks for having me.

BARTIROMO: So, your auction of nearly 18,000 comics just closed last night. How did it go?

ZURZOLO: We had a record week last week. Closed from Monday through Friday last week, and preauction estimated were $4 to $5 million. We broke $7 million on the auction.

BARTIROMO: That's incredible.

ZURZOLO: Yes. We can make the -

BARTIROMO: So, what do you think is behind this obsession with comic books that we have.

ZURZOLO: Well, I think people are very nostalgic and they're trying to recapture the happiest times of their life, their childhood. But I also think it has a lot to do with the - that comic books have become commodities. They are all encapsulated in hard plastic holders from CGC grading company which is the world's largest grading company. And they are encapsulated in these comic book holders, and it makes people who don't know how to grade a comic book makes them able to buy and sell comic books.

BARTIROMO: You know, it's interesting because actually we're looking - I was thinking, yes, there is that, that we want to relive our childhood, and I'm thinking, "Well, that's really wholesome, right?" But some comics are not wholesome. I've seen a lot of comics. My husband likes comic books. And some of these comic books get serious. I mean, it's not so wholesome.

ZURZOLO: Well, they're not all for little kids.

BARTIROMO: Right. Exactly. Like my husband.

ZURZOLO: You know, so there are - there you go. Exactly.

BARTIROMO: So, what is the attraction, do you think?

ZURZOLO: So, I think it's nostalgia, I think it's this idea that you - it's a form of entertainment, it's escapism, it's a form of investing. People are not so in love with - I think nowadays ever since the recession, traditional forms of investment. They have to have - become their own type of investor. So, they look at things they love, tangible assets like vintage comic books.

BARTIROMO: And one of them that you brought in was the comic in which Superman appears for the second time. Let's look at that one here. How much does that one go for at all?

ZURZOLO: This comic book, the second cover appearance of Superman went for $188,000. What's important about this is, this is the court case copy. This was used when D.C. Comics sued Fox who had made an intimation Superman back in the 40s, 30s and 40s. And -

BARTIROMO: Let's show that one. That's this one right here. Yes.

ZURZOLO: Yes. Because if you the stamp, the court case stamp.

BARTIROMO: So this is the court case stamp. Wow. Because they made a Superman -

ZURZOLO: Yes, Wonderman who was kind of a rip off from Superman. But this is the comic book that sold for the most in our auction is the first appearance of Superman in action comics number one. Now, my company holds records, world record. We sold the first million-dollar comic book, 1.5, 2.2, and over 3 million. This copy is conserved. It has a little bit of conservation done to it to maintain the structural integrity. This comic book, we estimated to sell for about $200 to $250,000, sold for $393,000.

BARTIROMO: Oh, my God. What -- now what does a collector do with that? Just keep it covered and it's just - that's the price.

ZURZOLO: I think it's in their safe or something like that.

BARTIROMO: $300,000 for a comic?

ZURZOLO: $393,000.

BARTIROMO: That's incredible. Almost 400 grand for this cover. Batman, a significant character in D.C. Comics. Why did that one bring in such a large amount of money? Tell us about the Batman.

ZURZOLO: So, Detective Comics #27, the first appearance of Batman. This comic book is actually restored. If it wasn't restored, it would sell for over a million dollars easy. This comic we estimated to sell for about 200 to 250. It sold for $313,000. People love Batman, they love Superman. These are two of the biggest characters in the world.

BARTIROMO: You're right. But what about characters today? Are there new characters that have emerged today that perhaps could command these kinds of numbers?

ZURZOLO: You know, there's a comic book that came out. You might have heard of it, The Walking Dead.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Yes.

ZURZOLO: Yes. Well, it's a huge T.V. show. Walking dead is huge. That's comic book in perfect condition. The number one copy can sell for over $3,000, which is really exciting. Our company will be bringing the world's best collection of Walking Dead to auction later this year to coincide with New York Comic-Con as well as an original art collection that's going to blow the minds of many people around the world.

BARTIROMO: And how do you choose something like that, Walking Dead. Why did you think Walking Dead would be a good thing?

ZURZOLO: I never did. You know, it's not my market. But I started reading them and a comic book done in black and white that was done so effectively. It was just amazing. When you read the original comic book, you understand why it's become a worldwide phenomenon.

BARTIROMO: Fascinating. Vincent, great to have you. Thanks so much for walking us through it.

ZURZOLO: Thank you very much.

BARTIROMO: Vincent Zurzolo there. We'll take a break. When we come back, Congressman Steve Scalise's condition has improved. He is upgraded from critical to serious, just coming after he was shoot last week during baseball practice with other Republican lawmakers. The details next hour. MORNINGS WITH MARIA back in a moment.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Good Monday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us, I'm Maria Bartiromo, and it is Monday, June 19th. Here are your top stories 7 a.m. on the East Coast.

Breaking news this morning. London on edge again. At least one person has been killed, several -

END

Rolls Into Texas; Bezos' Wealth Soars; Koepka Wins U.S. Open; Deadly2017-06-19T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:07:54ZLexisNexisLondon On Edge; Conway On Tech CEO Meeting; Syrian Jet Shot down; G.M. Rolls Into Texas; Bezos' Wealth Soars; Koepka Wins U.S. Open; DeadlyLanhamFULL TEXT

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN HOST: Welcome back. Good Monday morning everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo. And it is Monday, June 19th. Your top stories right now 8:00 a.m. on the East Coast.

Breaking news this morning, London has been targeted again at least one killed, several others injured after a man plows his van into a crowd near a mosque. Police are treating this as terrorist attack this morning.

Technology executives are descending on the White House today, top leaders in the industry set to focus on updating the government's I.T. system on the CEOs attending, Apple CEO Tim Cook, Microsoft's Satya Nadella, IBM's Ginni Rometty among others.

The agenda also top priorities, Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell is setting a July 4th deadline for a health care vote out of the Senate. Counselor to the President, Kellyanne Conway weighed in on that, push, last hour.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

KELLYANNE CONWAY, COUNSELOR TO THE PRESIDENT: But the president is forging ahead, he's in close contact with Leader McConnell on health care reform. You know, Obamacare has been a long live for over seven years. These sinking battleships turn slowly and they've got part one through the house, now the Senate will do its work.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Meanwhile, Britain is working on its exit from the European Union, the negotiations under way today, beginning today, a look at what's is ahead and at stake coming up. Blue Apron set the range for an upcoming for initial public offering, the details as the company seeks evaluation of more than $3 billion dollars, pricing 30 million shares this morning. Futures indicating a higher opening for the broader averages, technology once again leadership here, tech stocks are leading the markets with the Dow Industrials up 73 points right here, NASDAQ expected to be up better than 40 points. This right here, that's the high of the morning.

In Europe, also strength although the European indices are off of their highs, the CAC quarante in Paris is still up almost one percent, as is the DAX Index in Germany. In Asia overnight, markets finished higher with Hong Kong the best performer, up better than one percent overnight. All those coming up and this morning, joining me to talk all about it, Maslansky and Partners President, Lee Carter, Rosecliff Capital chief executive officer Mike Murphy and Diligence President, Mike Baker. Great conversation, great to have you guys here today.

MIKE BAKER. PRESIDENT AND CO-FOUNDER. DILIGENCE: Yes, great. I just want to --

LEE CARTER, PRESIDENT, MASLANSKY + PARTNERS: Great to be here.

BAKER: -- just maybe above my abilities or my pay grade, I'm loss to explain how Blue Apron is valuing at $3 billion.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

CARTER: I mean, I want to know with their attention right now.

BARTIROMO: What is it?

MIKE MURPHY, EF EXECUTIVE OFFICER, ROSECLIFF CAPITAL CHI: That will do a billion in revenue, three-billion-dollar price. It's not that far-fetched.

BARTIROMO: They say they want to price it between 15 and 17 dollars a share and 30 million shares. Do you think that -- do you think that makes sense?

MURPHY: I think it's fair, it's a company that did 800 million in revenue last year, that will do a billion in revenue this year and they're the biggest in the space. Now, Amazon and Whole Foods getting together coming in there, could mean something else, but I think this evaluation is fair.

BAKER: What's the bottom line, what are they making and what's their profit?

MURPHY: Next question, they're losing money.

BAKER: OK.

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: They are losing money but they are growing revenue and that's what you think is the base. We'll talk more about this. President Trump is meeting with some of the nation's top technology CEOs at the White House today. Adam Shapiro is at the White House right now with the preview. Adam, good morning to you.

BLAKE BURMAN, FBN WASHINGTON CORRESPONDENT: And a good morning to you, Maria. This is the inaugural meeting of the American Technology Council and the biggest names in technology will be here for several hours talking about ways to modernize the U.S. government. Let me give you some of the names that are going to arrive here very shortly. Jeff Bezos from Amazon, Safra Catz from Oracle, Tim Cook from Apple, you've got Satya Nadella from Microsoft, the CEO from IBM and of course, Eric Schmidt, chairman of Alphabet, the company we used to call Google.

They're going to be discussing ways to streamline the I.T. services in the government which in some cases 10 to 20 years behind current status of what's expected in the private sector but here's what Kellyanne Conway had to say about these CEOs coming here today.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

CONWAY: What Jared did, he invited in the five -- the five brightest tech people are five tech experts from DOD. Five from veterans affairs have said, how can we get this together? (INAUDIBLE) now we have a system in place where veterans are retreated as one single patient seamlessly.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BURMAN: You heard Kellyanne Conway refer to Jared, Jared Kushner who the president charged with overseeing a streamlining of the U.S. government but the president also signed on May 1st an executive order to modernize the U.S. government. Some of the topics the CEOs will be discussing on ways to modernize, electronic medical records, you can take anywhere from three months to six months to transfer medical records to the V.A. system, so they're going to try and streamline that, the H-1B visa program, they're going to try to eliminate fraud in that program, and then, of course, artificial intelligence focusing on machine learning as well as big data and the ways that the U.S. government can securely store data in the cloud.

A senior administration official talking to Fox Business said, here is what we can expect, "These are things that are going to require years to really make significant progress on and our systems are in some cases 10 to 20 years out of date, so we're not going to fix that in one day. But we have to start now." And now Maria is today, they will be here in the next few hours and the president will meet with them toward the end of the day. Back to you.

BARTIROMO: All right, Adam. We'll come back to you as news develops. Thank you. Adam Shapiro at the White House this morning. CONWAY: Well the president and his counterterrorism team assess this situation throughout the night. And so we know that people are very concerned about national security, it's in large part how the president won. Hillary Clinton referred to them as our, "determined enemies" at her convention speech so I think there's a huge contrast. BARTIROMO: Yes, he really did. And I think that's why it's just a head scratch as far as why he gets this pushback on the travel ban and everything else.

Meanwhile, there are new questions surrounding whether or not the president is actually under investigation or not by the Special Counsel looking into Russia's alleged election meddling. CONWAY: Well I don't think Jay Sekulow, the president (inaudible) contradicting the tweet, I think he explained it. What Mr. Sekulow said is that is that the president is constrained by the 140 characters in Twitter.

The president uses his social media platform to communicate directly with the people as you know Maria. But that Jay Sekulow, his per -- one of his personal lawyers said the president has not been notified that he's under investigation. In fact, Mr. Comey testified that the president is not the president said in the letter where he dismissed Mr. Comey in May, that Comey had told him three times that he wasn't under investigation, they've not been notified otherwise. His personal lawyer would know this.

His lawyer is saying no he's not. So I think he's explaining that the president is really pointing out the irony of everything and the last part of his tweet is the most important which is that he consider this to be a witch hunt.

We've been doing this for many, many months now having an investigation, where's the collusion? Where's the obstruction of justice? Where's the evidence that supports this conclusion and we have separate, what, five or six different separate congressional investigations going on and we've been doing this for eight to nine months, I mean you could have a baby in this time and they have no evidence.

BARTIROMO: Well look, I have been very adamant about this as well from the beginning saying, look, this is a -- it looks like a completely manufactured story. However, why respond to the Washington Post do you think Kellyanne? I mean the idea of tweeting, I understand he's speaking directly to the American people, people like it and it's been a good strategy for him. But can you convince him or ask him why he's not tweeting about the agenda? Why he's not tweeting about other -- why bring up the Russia story and respond to the Washington Post when this is a news organization he's called fake news anyway.

CONWAY: So here's where everybody has to wake up each morning and make their own choices. The media could cover all of his tweets and if they did that, they would see that he more often tweets about agenda items than other matters.

He has this constant stream on Instagram, on Facebook, on Twitter, his big social media platform where he says reaches about 100 million people, Maria. And you had the entire day in Cuba the other day where he rolled back these awful rules that Obama put in place that allowed the Cuban Regime not the Cuban people to benefit financially. We had the first meeting at the White House with the Opioid Commission on Friday. Earlier in the week the president did workforce development and apprenticeship week, that's all on Twitter.

All of that goes on to his Twitter feed when he has a bilateral. So we want to dignify all types of career paths, all types of jobs, the welders, the hairdressers, the plumbers, the carpenters, people who get a high school diploma and a skill certificate. All of that's on the social media platform, they just don't want to cover it.

BARTIROMO: All right. I think that's a fair point. I mean, but there is criticism that the president brings up things that he doesn't really need to. I mean does he create some obstacles for himself by bringing up some of the things that perhaps the supporters don't believe anyway?

CONWAY: Well in this case though he -- first of all, he's the president of all Americans and he made that clear beginning on November 9th and he's never wavered from that.

People who criticize him and even deny that the legitimacy of his presidency will benefit from his tax cut, they will benefit from better healthcare, they will be benefit from infrastructure, they will benefit from ISIS in retreat, they will benefit from the regulatory framework being chipped away because it's impeding our pocketbook in a personal liberty issues. BARTIROMO: The witch hunt is what he calls it.

BARTIROMO: You know, I think the left has been really driving this narrative in terms of the Russia probe from the get-go since the president took office. What can the president do to keep the team on focus on the agenda?
